. <app><lem type="conj">tuṅgal</lem><rdg wit="#A" cause="dittography">tugal lavan</rdg></app> saṅ sevaka darma, lavan saṅ pandita, tuṅgalakən saṅ mavarah lavan saṅ matakvan, saṅ pandita mari mavarah ri saṅ sevaka darma, mari matakon saṅ yogisvara.</p>
1910<p xml:id="smg_46.03" xml:lang="kaw-Latn">ka, lamun huvus pada
. <app><lem type="emn">vruh</lem><rdg wit="#A">vraḥ</rdg></app> kabeh, lavan pramananya, kitu pada muliyanya, pada mulih ri jatinya ṅaranna, ya <pb edRef="#A" n="36v"/>ta sinaṅguh
. <app><lem type="emn">sabdopadesa</lem><rdg wit="#A">sab·dapadesa</rdg></app> ṅaranya, kayatnakna saṅ sevaka
. <app><lem type="emn">darma</lem><rdg wit="#A">dama</rdg></app>, liṅ arya mahapandita.</p>
.</div>
1915<div xml:id="smg_47">
.<ab xml:id="smg_47.01" type="colophon">ini kayatnakna ṅaranna, saṅ
. <app><lem type="norm">hyaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">hya</rdg></app> pustaka, sasana mahaguru ṅaranna pun, təlas sinurat riṅ vulan kapat, manibakən sastra, ri desa mahapavitra, riṅ gunuṅ jədaṅ pun, ulih sambian ṅeñca pun, saṅ anurat
. <app><lem type="norm">boñcah</lem><rdg wit="#A">bvacah</rdg></app> nu ṅaheraṅ nimbaṅ kañcana pun, malampah
. <app><lem type="norm">iṅampura</lem><rdg wit="#A">iṅapura</rdg></app>, ku na sastra rocek kadi tapak yuyu riṅ
1920 <app><lem type="norm">tañcaṅ</lem><rdg wit="#A">tacaṁ</rdg></app> pun, ləvih lvaṅan kuraṅ tinabəhan kena bənaṅ nu irəg, pun.</ab>
. </div>
. </div>
. <div type="translation"> <div n="1" corresp="#smg_01"><p corresp="#smg_01.01">Here is the name of the holy book: The Holy Instruction of the Great Teacher (<foreign>Saṅ Hyaṅ Sasana Mahaguru</foreign>). <foreign>Sasana</foreign> means the legacy of the ancestors, <foreign>maha</foreign> means more superior than the superior of the world, <foreign>guru</foreign> means the source of all the universe.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_01.02">There is your analogy: like the priceless jewel and the most desirable gem, it is the source of the joy and sorrow, the bad and the good. Its explanation is as follows: world (<foreign>buh</foreign>),<note>msA has <foreign>bvah</foreign>, but I render it as <foreign>buh</foreign> since the context is quite clear that <foreign>bvah</foreign> is the earth <foreign>prətivi</foreign>. Cf. <foreign>bvar</foreign> for <foreign>bur</foreign> in SMG 1.4.</note> intention,<note>I interpret <foreign>paksa</foreign> as ‘intention’, according to one of the meaning in OJ; see OJED, s.v. <foreign>pakṣa</foreign> IV.</note> knowledge,<note>In OS texts, for instance in for instance in KaPañ 6–7, we find that <foreign>huniṅ</foreign> is a verb ‘to know’: <foreign>avakanən saṅ sisya, nu huniṅ sevaka darma</foreign> “to be practiced by the disciple, who knows how to serve <foreign>dharma</foreign>”. but in this context it is clearly substantive.</note> determination,<note>Based on the explanation that <foreign>təmən</foreign> is related to fire, maybe it means determination. OJED does not record substantive meaning, but cf. <foreign>anəməni</foreign> ‘to be serious about, set about doing st. in real earnest (determinedly)’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>təmən</foreign>).</note> total willingness.</p>
1925<p corresp="#smg_01.03">The meaning is: The world is the Holy Earth. When it is beautified, degraded, upgraded, littered, mingled, it does not fall<note>The meaning of fall is taken from MdS, <foreign>nyusutkeun</foreign> ‘throw so. down forward on the ground’; <foreign>tisusut</foreign> ‘fall forward’. Cf Mal. <foreign>susut</foreign> ‘to decrease; to shrink’. It is different from OJ <foreign>susut</foreign> ‘entangled, confused.’</note> and it is not indignant, it is not weak<note>I interpret <foreign>gərah</foreign> as ‘weak, powerless’ as in OJ. In MdS, it has a positive nuance ‘cheerful, buoyant, in high spirits; rejoice, glad, pleased, happy’.</note>
. and it is not restless,<note><foreign>bijah</foreign>: in MdS dictionaries, <foreign>mijah</foreign> is considered as the base word. Clearly in OS we have the base word <foreign>bijah</foreign> ‘restless’.</note> forcefull and firm in performing earthiness (<foreign>kaprativian</foreign>). That is indeed the thing that the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should practice.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_01.04">Intention means the water. Its benefit is when <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> emerges<note>The word <foreign>bvar</foreign> is not in the dictionaries, but cf. MdS <foreign>bur</foreign>. ‘ant. for: hurry off, hasten away, scamper off, fly away, strew (flowers), scatter, sow (seed), sprinkle (sand), pour out, empty (contents of st.), etc’.</note> from its upstream. It gushes clear, and it feels cool. Moreover, it also had no obstacles, reaching the ocean. That is what the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> must emulate.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_01.05">Knowledge means the wind. Its benefit is when it blows <note>Like the word <foreign>bvar</foreign>, a single syllable word <foreign>hir</foreign> is also, following Hardjadibrata’s terminology, an anticipator. However, <foreign>hir</foreign> in this sense is not recorded in MdS dictionaries, but the present context makes clear that it refers to ‘air motion, wind etc’. Cf. MdS <foreign>hiliwir</foreign>, <foreign>ngahiliwir</foreign> ‘(come in) blowing softly (of the breeze, of the scent of flowers filling the air); <foreign>humiliwir</foreign> s.m. (in lit. lang.); (the root is used as ant.)’.</note> from the west. It blows with coolness, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> feels smooth on our bodies. Moreover, it will not be obstructed when it appears at the right moment in the world. That is what the servant of the dharma must emulate.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_01.06">Determination means fire and weapons. Because of their natures (<foreign>ti iña</foreign>),<note>I take the conjunction <foreign>ti</foreign> in <foreign>ti iña</foreign> as the reasoning. Cf. Skt. <foreign>tasmat</foreign>.</note>
1930 they are to be used<note>The passive form <foreign>dipipakənakən</foreign> is from <foreign>pakən</foreign> ‘for, so that’, cf. an equivalent construction in Mal. <foreign>diperuntukkan</foreign>.</note> by people whose minds are determined.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_01.07">Willingness means the Holy Sun. When it rises from the east, it is not impeded by clouds, rain, smoke, and fog until it reaches the west, because of the concentration on one action <supplied reason="subaudible">only</supplied>. That is what the servant of the dharma must emulate. We should not fail to be mindful toward the holy original cause. The following are called The Five Knowledges (<foreign>pañca-vedani</foreign>). <note>The word <foreign>vedani</foreign> ‘knowledge’ is probably being understood by the author as a neutral form of Skt. <foreign>veda</foreign>. Another possibility is that the author tends to relate <foreign>vedani</foreign> with the OJ compound, <foreign>ve dani</foreign> ‘clear water’, from OJ <foreign>ve</foreign> ‘water’, and <foreign>dani</foreign> ‘(of the mind) to become clear, no longer darkened by emotions, etc?’.</note> <foreign>Panca</foreign> means <foreign>five</foreign>, <foreign>ve</foreign> means water, <foreign>dani</foreign> means broomstick.</p></div>
.<div n="2" corresp="#smg_02"><p corresp="#smg_02.01">This is called the precepts for society (<foreign>siksa kandaṅ</foreign>), the precepts of religious groups (<foreign>siksa kuruṅ</foreign>), the root’s precepts (<foreign>siksa dapur</foreign>). The meaning is: the precepts for society are around yourself. To encounter<note>The initial reduplication form <foreign>jəṅjəəṅ</foreign> means ‘to encounter’, from <foreign>jəəṅ</foreign> ‘to see’. We find another variant <foreign>jəjəəṅ</foreign> in OS corpus. Cf. SKK 7.2.</note> the adultery, the adultery of ‘The Journey’ <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> of ‘The Sitting Place’. That is what we should keep in mind.<note>One would expect <foreign>ku uraṅ</foreign> instead of <foreign>dəṅ uraṅ</foreign>. This combination is unusual. However, cf. the attested use of conjunction <foreign>mvaṅ</foreign> in OJ (equivalent to OS <foreign>dəṅ</foreign>) as a mark of agent, e.g. in JS 19 <foreign>kapāśa mvaṅ triguṇa</foreign> ‘to be fettered by the <foreign>triguna</foreign>s’.</note> Then let us be careful, in case we enter the yard, entering the inner place, it is not comfortable <supplied reason="subaudible">if we are</supplied> not their inhabitants. That is called the precepts for society.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_02.02">When we are on a journey,<note>The word <foreign>paparan</foreign> is from <foreign>paran</foreign> ‘destination’, meaning ‘to go, in journey’, cf. OJ <foreign>apara-paran</foreign> ‘to journey, wander abroad, roam’. This form is not recorded in MdS, however, some dialects have <foreign>maparan</foreign> ‘go to see so., going to look so. up’ (Hardjadibrata, s.v. <foreign>paran</foreign>). Cf. SKK 5.3.</note> it is not proper to commit a deceitful act because of the commodity of someone else’s farm, or someone else’s vegetable grove. Therefore, “<foreign>hiris</foreign> will smash the ear when the bean smashes the forehead”:<note><foreign>hiris məbət cəli, lamun kacaṅ məbət taraṅ</foreign> “hiris will smash the ear when the bean smashes the forehead” seems to be an expression. It possibly refers to the cause and consequence of someone’s action. In MdS, <foreign>hiris</foreign> refers to various kinds of plant, ‘leguminous plant (s.m. kacang h., see <foreign>kacang</foreign>); <foreign>ki hiris</foreign> I k.o. shrub, Budleia asiatica Lour., member of the Loganiaceae (also called: <foreign>ki kadal</foreign>, <foreign>ki kérését</foreign>, ki <foreign>monyényén</foreign>); II (H.) k.o. shrub or small tree (wood useful for charcoal; also called: <foreign>ki hurung</foreign>). Since it is mentioned along with <foreign>kacaṅ</foreign>, I take <foreign>hiris</foreign> as a kind of nut.</note> to collect what people put down temporarily (<foreign>tunda</foreign>),<note>In MdS, <foreign>tunda</foreign>, <foreign>nunda</foreign> means ‘put st. down temporarily (with the purpose of taking it up again later on the way); stop st. (work, case, subject) temporarily (with the intention of picking it up again at a later stage)’. Combined with the verb <foreign>ṅala</foreign>, I prefer to render <foreign>tunda</foreign> as a substantive.</note> to take something clearly owned <supplied reason="subaudible">by another</supplied>,<note>In MdS, <foreign>kantenan</foreign> is a high (<foreign>lemes</foreign>) register of <foreign>puguh</foreign> ‘(adv) of course, certainly, sure, positive’; or is it a <foreign>lemes</foreign> register of <foreign>kari</foreign> ‘remain, residue’? If it is the case, then the alternative translation of <foreign>ṅala kantənan</foreign> would be ‘to collect the remains’.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> to bring down someone else’s tap (<foreign>sadapan</foreign>). It is improper to defecate on the side of the road, for it would be smelt by those who are careless,<note>The reduplicated form <foreign>buṅah-baṅah</foreign> is not found in dictionaries. MdS has <foreign>balaṅah</foreign> ‘careless’, probably from <foreign>baṅah</foreign> with infix <foreign>-al-</foreign>. The base word <foreign>bangah</foreign>, however, is not recorded in dictionaries.</note> for it is possible that you will be cursed and be blamed<note>The passive word <foreign>kapadahkən</foreign> is not found in MdS. Its occurrence is always with <foreign>kasumpah</foreign> ‘to be cursed’ in OS texts. I render it as equivalent to OJ <foreign>amāda</foreign> ‘to find fault with, judge harshly’, from the base <foreign>vāda</foreign> (OJED, s.v.). It should be noted that MdS also has <foreign>ngawada</foreign> ‘to criticize’.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">by</supplied> mother, father, and teachers. We should not fail to wear loincloths and full attire; if we meet a gusti or a minister, we should be on their left <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> bow.<note>The word <foreign>paṅadoṅkoṅkən</foreign> is clearly related to OJ <foreign>joṅkoṅ</foreign> ’squatting’. Cf. SKK 4.16. See the discussion on <foreign>paN- -kən</foreign> in Chapter 3. Cf. also MdS <foreign>dongko</foreign> vi. ‘bend the upper torso forward’, but MdS also has <foreign>dongkong</foreign> ‘id.’ <foreign>mangdongkokeun</foreign> ‘take a bent forward posture for so’.</note> Those are called the precepts for society.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_02.03">The precepts of the religious group (<foreign>siksa kuruṅ</foreign>) are to be one action with the scholar. After all,<note>Based on the context, <foreign>aṅgəs ma</foreign> here seems to mean ‘after all’. </note> it is not good to make trouble of which has been deliberated, violating the holy precepts. If we are aware of the sections (of the books) and their binding cords (<foreign>ləkər-ləkər</foreign>),<note>The reduplication form <foreign>ləkər-ləkər</foreign> is not attested in OS, but we find <foreign>ləkər</foreign> in OJ ‘coil, encircling rope (etc) to provide firmness’ (OJED, s.v.). I interpret it as an allusion to the binding cords on the palm leaf manuscripts.</note> their <foreign>danda</foreign>s,<note>The word <foreign>daṅda-daṅdi</foreign> probably refers to Sanskrit term <foreign>daṇḍa</foreign> or punctuation mark in writing. It seems to be a twin form. Cf. <foreign>trəpti-trəptva</foreign> on SMG 3.2.</note>lines (<foreign>sipat</foreign>), enclosures (<foreign>galəṅ</foreign>), their strokes, their compositions, their boundary, their limits, all the imprints of the God Brahmā and Viṣṇu when they delimited the world. That is called the precepts of the religious group.</p>
1935<p corresp="#smg_02.04">As for the precepts of the root is to reach the core, to obtain the origin by one’s devoted and truthful mind toward the scholar. That is called the precepts of the root. Those are called the precepts for society,<note>One expected <foreign>siksa kandaṅ</foreign>, <foreign>siksa kuruṅ</foreign>, <foreign>siksa dapur ṅaranya</foreign> in this sentence. Probably manuscript is corrupted in this part.</note> according to the great scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="3" corresp="#smg_03"><p corresp="#smg_03.01">As follows is what the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should be aware of, <supplied reason="subaudible">that is</supplied> the original cause of the holy scripture,<note>For the interpretation regarding the writing supports and instruments in manuscript production, see Aditia Gunawan 2015.</note> the form of stain<note>Maybe <foreign>mala-murti</foreign> refers to the shape of the ink stains in the book? But <foreign>mala</foreign> can also mean ‘curse’, which in this connection probably displays the sacred nature of the book.</note> in the past until present.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_03.02">Here is the beginning of the holy scripture. Its form is as follows: after the sun<note>The sun with the personification attribute is also found in SHH 24.6, <foreign>śrīvikramāditya</foreign>: <foreign>hana maṇik sarveṣṭa sakārja paripūraka ṅaranya, cinaritakən ri carita kumara mvaṅ saṅ murti mvaṅ śrīvikramāditya</foreign>.</note> had set, the night replaced <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied>. Satisfaction and pleasure<note>I consider <foreign>trəpti-trəptva</foreign> as a twin form, equivalent to OJ <foreign>trəpti</foreign> and <foreign>trəpta</foreign>, both mean ‘contentment, gladness, well-being; content, glad, pleased’ (OJED, svv.).</note> are the cause of the way of appearing, <supplied reason="subaudible">thanks to</supplied> the reality of time of the Goddess Durgi. The God Gana’s instrument (<foreign>jantra</foreign>) trumpeted, so that it was sprayed towards humankind in the middle realm, and it turned into <foreign>gebang</foreign> and <foreign>lontar</foreign>. <supplied reason="subaudible">When</supplied> the time came for the gebang and lontar to form young leaves, they followed precisely the same pattern with respect to their width and length, <supplied reason="subaudible">so that they could have</supplied> <foreign>asta gaṅga vira tanu</foreign> applied.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_03.03">What is the <foreign>asta gaṅga vira tanu</foreign>? <foreign>Asta</foreign> means hand, <foreign>gaṅga</foreign> means water, <foreign>vira</foreign> means pen and brush, <foreign>tanu</foreign> means ink. They are used for writing by the scholar, for reading by one without knowledge to increase the range of the sounds, which is constrained <supplied reason="subaudible">according to the rules</supplied> by the poet.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_03.04">In the first place, the ten origins will be narrated. <foreign>Oṅ</foreign> Saraswati the excellence mind<note>The combination <foreign>tara-jñana</foreign> is unattested elsewhere. My interpretation of <foreign>tara</foreign> as ‘excellent’ is based on the meaning in OJ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>tara</foreign> 1).</note> and the thought-gem. Let the eyes of God Bayu widely open. Let there be the embodiment of Lord Guru, the accomplished ancient masters<note>The compound <foreign>panditatita</foreign> is from <foreign>pandita</foreign> (Skt <foreign>paṇḍita</foreign>) and <foreign>atita</foreign> (Skt <foreign>atīta</foreign>) ‘former’.</note> from the earth, the accomplished ancien masters from the sky: Kusika, Garga, Méstri, Purusya, Patañjala; also breath, speech, and mind; let alone The Witness,<note>On the interpretation of The Witness (Saṅ Manon), see chapter 11, §The God and The Soul.</note> for He is the one who counts.</p>
1940<p corresp="#smg_03.05">As follows are what are called the ten origins (<foreign>dasa-purva</foreign>). <foreign>Dasa</foreign> means ten, <foreign>purva</foreign> means the origin. Those should be taken notice by the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>, according to the scholar.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_03.06">Postphone! All that emerges from the narrative (<foreign>carita</foreign>) should be followed; <supplied reason="subaudible">yet</supplied> the essence of The One (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ tuṅgal</foreign>) is inactive. For what purpose am I uttering this mantra? Well, it is because I know that I wish to produce letters: writing on gold, writing on silver, writing on copper, writing on knives (?, <foreign>cudiga</foreign>),<note>In BM 1565–1569, <foreign>cudiga</foreign> seems to refer to one of the metal materials, however, Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw translate <foreign>cudiga</foreign> as ‘spout’: <foreign>pañcuran tambaga sukla, caṅkorah salaka pirak, dituṅtuṅ ku cudiga, pesek dipopokan omas, pañimbəh undəm salaka</foreign> “The bathing place is of light copper, with a silver basin, ending in a spout, a washing place coated with gold, its scoop a silver vessel”. I rather consider that <foreign>cudiga</foreign> is derived from Skt. <foreign>churikā</foreign> ‘knife’, with the interchangeability of /r/ with /d/ and /k/ with /g/, which is not extraordinary. I wonder if there is a semantic shift from a knife into a general material of metal like ‘steel’, since it is placed after copper and before iron</note> writing on iron, writing on stone, writing on wooden strips, writing on bamboo (?, <foreign>pəjva</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>pəjva</foreign> could not be found in dictionaries. But this word may be related with OJ <foreign>peñjor</foreign> ‘bamboo pole decorated at the top’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>peñjor</foreign>), the changement of vowels /e/ gt /ə/, while the omission of a nasal and the addition of final /r/ are imaginable. However, the connection with <foreign>ləpihan</foreign> which, according to Jákl (2016a), means ‘folded’ is also problematic. I do not exclude the possibility that <foreign>pəjva</foreign> may mean bark tree (<foreign>daluwang</foreign>), which is also used as a writing support for manuscripts.</note> writing on <foreign>lontar</foreign>,<note>Regarding the word <foreign>taal</foreign> (= <foreign>lontar</foreign> palm-leaf), we find several cases of the hiatus usage in OS which is comparable to long vowels in OJ counterpart: OS <foreign>vaas</foreign> vs. OJ <foreign>vās</foreign>, OS <foreign>duum</foreign> vs. OJ <foreign>dūm</foreign>. See chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> writing on <foreign>gebang</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_03.07">Writing on gold is called ‘transcendent ruby and gold’; its form and its result is beautiful, for it may not be stored. Perhaps many do not know this, so once again it is passed down: writing on silver is called ‘silver’ (<foreign>kanaka</foreign>). It is passed down again: writing on copper is called ‘thin plates of beaten gold’ (?, <foreign>paripih</foreign>).<note>The word <foreign>paripid</foreign> seems to be related to Skt. <foreign>paripīḍ</foreign> ‘to press all round, press together, squeeze’. However, I interpret this word to be equivalent OJ <foreign>paripih</foreign>, meaning ‘thin plates of beaten gold’. Should it be better to emend it to <foreign>paripih</foreign>? However, the difference between OJ /h/ and OS /d/ is difficult to understand. Cf. Mal. <foreign>pipih</foreign> ‘thin and flat’.</note> It is passed down again: writing on steel is called ‘pressed’ (?, <foreign>prəka</foreign>).<note>The interpretation of <foreign>prəka</foreign> as ‘to be pressed’ is tentative. I relate this word to OJ <foreign>prək, maprək, umrək</foreign> ‘pressed up close, to press against’.</note> It is passed down again: writing on iron is called ‘family’ (?, <foreign>gvatraka</foreign>). It is passed down again: writing on stone is called ‘dead heirs’ (?, <foreign>tras pati</foreign>).<note>The compound <foreign>tras pati</foreign> literally means ‘dead heirs’; I wonder whether this contains an allusion to the more durable nature of the inscription on stone and is intended for heirs?</note> It is passed down again: writing on wooden boards is called ‘a bench’ (<foreign>salə</foreign>). It is passed down again: writing on bamboo is called ‘folded’ (?, <foreign>ləpihan</foreign>), which may not be kept for it may cause danger. It is passed down again: writing on lontar is called incising (<foreign>carik</foreign>), indeed it has its virtues for it is not to be used for sacred texts (<foreign>kabuyutan</foreign>). Let’s go down again: writing on gebang is called black (<foreign>cəməṅ</foreign>), and this is for the sacred texts. For such texts referred to as manuscripts (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ ripta</foreign>), <supplied reason="subaudible">the means for attaining</supplied> emptiness (<foreign>sunya</foreign>), folded books (<foreign>ləpihan</foreign>), the weapons (?, <foreign>mastra</foreign>),<note>My interpretation of <foreign>mastra</foreign> as ‘weapon’ is tentative, probably it should be read <foreign>makastra</foreign>? Cf. PM 41b <foreign>makastra tanah ləpihan eñjiṅ mahas andon laṅu pañji</foreign></note> the smearing (of ink ?, <foreign>lepa-karana</foreign>),<note>The activity of smearing (<foreign>lepa-karana</foreign>) probably refers to the smearing of palm leaves manuscripts as we find its practice in Bali nowadays? This combination is not found in OJ.</note> these are the <supplied reason="subaudible">types of</supplied> books enumerated one by one. Those are called ten advancements.</p></div>
.<div n="4" corresp="#smg_04"><p corresp="#smg_04.01">The One said, “What is the purpose<note>The word <foreign>piənanana</foreign>, which I interpret tentatively ‘purpose’, is not found in MdS dictionaries and in the OS corpus at my disposal, but I wonder whether the semantic meaning is generated from the morphological process of <foreign>pi- -ən</foreign> meaning ‘things to be’ or ‘purpose’ and it becomes the base word <foreign>piən</foreign> with suffix <foreign>-an</foreign> and the enclitic -<foreign>ana</foreign>; cf. <foreign>pikavihən</foreign> ‘things to be sung’.</note> of this holy book? Because I know that I will produce the composition, being the emergence of The Teacher’s Precepts (<foreign>Siksa Guru</foreign>), from the holy precepts.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_04.02">Here, as follows, is the pure circle of three bodily domains. This is what should be thrown out; the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should not follow that (i.e. <foreign>tri-mala</foreign>)<note>The allusion to the <foreign>tri-mala</foreign> can only be understood in the light of the source of this text, SiGu 8.3; cf. also SMG 4.3 below.</note> — <supplied reason="subaudible">for it is</supplied> the source of sadness, the origin of the sins leading to misery, the beginning of the <foreign>kali</foreign>’s era, the cause of the sins leading to hell — the three stains so it is called.</p>
1945<p corresp="#smg_04.03"><supplied reason="subaudible">As far as the</supplied> categorizations <supplied reason="subaudible">are concerned</supplied>, their comparisons are as follows: what is called the three defects is like bronze and wax, copper and tin. What is comparable to copper and tin? The meaning is the three evils: improper speeches, improper acts, improper minds. Evil speeches, evil acts, and evil minds are performed.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_04.04">These are the manifestations of the evil acts: flicking with the knuckle of finger, tapping, stabbing, punching, striking, knocking, hitting, slapping, spanking, all kinds of hand’s actions, those are called the evil acts.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_04.05">The evil speeches are: furious and angry without reason, talking rudely, cursing, blaming, condemning, uttering black magic, backbiting the teacher, all kinds of improper speeches, those are called the evil speeches.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_04.06">The evil minds are: plotting, pretending, slandering, using black magic, offending, bewitching, poisoning, being envious of what is right, including plundering, stealing, trespassing, infiltrating, way laying, anything that is improper is performed <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> intended, those are the evil minds. That is called the three defects.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_04.07">As follows are three ultimate defects (<foreign>tri-mala visesa</foreign>), possessed by the king, the elders, the hermits, the ritual expert, the sailor. This is the explanation: there is someone seen in sorrow, <supplied reason="subaudible">then he</supplied> is sold, enslaved, robbed, and murdered. Those are called the five sinful <supplied reason="subaudible">men</supplied>, all such things are considered the three ultimate defects, according to the scholar, 3.</p></div>
1950<div n="5" corresp="#smg_05"><p corresp="#smg_05.01">Again, as follows is what should be carefully noticed by the servant of the Truth. There are what are called the ten defilements.<note>On the concept of <foreign>dasa-kalesa</foreign>, see chapter 11, §Ten Stains and Defilements.</note> What is the evidence? Here is the verse, the statement is as follows:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_05.02">“This <supplied reason="subaudible">condition of</supplied> defilement and sin having disappeared, and those who are afflicted having disappeared, they do great meritorious conduct.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_05.03">The meaning is: you should be able to purify the ten defilements. If comes to you, namely: vice (<foreign>doṣa</foreign>), ignorance (<foreign>moha</foreign>), cupidity (<foreign>lobha</foreign>), madness (<foreign>məta</foreign>), jealousy (<foreign>mātsarya</foreign>), arrogance (<foreign>abhimāna</foreign>), stupidity (<foreign>mūrkha</foreign>), cheat (<foreign>kuhaka</foreign>), idle talk (<foreign>sambhinnapralāpa</foreign>), calumny (<foreign>peśuna</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_05.04">The meaning is: the vice (<foreign>doṣa</foreign>) is deeming oneself superior in happiness, deeming oneself superior in knowledge, deeming oneself strong, that is called the vice. Ignorance (<foreign>moha</foreign>) means not having affection toward fellow human beings. Cupidity (<foreign>lobha</foreign>) means addicted to eating, addicted to drinking, and continuously sleeping, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> does not want to think of goodness, that is called cupidity. Having a lot of things to think of, something to carry out, something to act on, that is called cupidity. Madness (<foreign>məta</foreign>) is being difficult<note>The word <foreign>ivuh</foreign> is not found in OS texts, but it is clear from OJ <foreign>ivuh</foreign> ‘difficult’. In OJ, <foreign>ivuh</foreign> is attested in a later text, KHvj 1.58a: <foreign>tuhv evuh təmah iṅ nagara</foreign> (OJED, s.v. <foreign>ivuh</foreign>).</note> by his wealth, being difficult by his expertise, being difficult by his qualities, being difficult by his knowledge, that is called madness (<foreign>məta</foreign>). Jealousy (<foreign>matsārya</foreign>) is being jealous to see the welfare <supplied reason="subaudible">of others</supplied>, jealous watching someone kind, jealous watching someone happy, that is called jealousy. Arrogance (<foreign>abhimāna</foreign>) means not willing to give lessons and advice, that is called arrogance. Stupidity (<foreign>mūrkha</foreign>) means not willing to obey mother, father, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> teachers, that is called stupidity. Cheat (<foreign>kuhaka</foreign>) means to claim the work of others. Idle talk (<foreign>sambhinnapralāpa</foreign>) means constantly talking about the pleasure of those who have the pleasure, the wealth of those who have wealth, that is called idle talk. Calumny (<foreign>peśuna</foreign>) means easily to be jealous, easily to be deceitful, to provoke <supplied reason="subaudible">others</supplied>. Those are called ten defilements.</p></div>
.<div n="6" corresp="#smg_06"><p corresp="#smg_06.01">Furthermore, the following are called the ten defects (<foreign>dasa-mala</foreign>). As follows is the verse:</p>
1955<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_06.02"><foreign>vigatah maladuhkhinaḥ, kurvanti kuśalam mahat</foreign>| <foreign>gavayakən sutəm citəm, budi hiyəm maguh narakəm</foreign> |</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_06.03">The meaning is: would you have the same probability of misfortune (<foreign>marakarma</foreign>), if <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> comes to you? Misfortune means sleep (<foreign>supta</foreign>), fear (<foreign>bhaya</foreign>), laziness (<foreign>tandrī</foreign>), irresolution (<foreign>kleda</foreign>), shame (<foreign>lajjā</foreign>), lust for women (<foreign>rāgastrī</foreign>), adultery (<foreign>paradāra</foreign>), eating of food (<foreign>bhakṣabhojana</foreign>), dishonest consideration (<foreign>kuṭilaviveka</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_06.04">The meaning is: sleep (<foreign>supta</foreign>) means continuously sleeping, forgetting to ask what is the good and the best for oneself, forgetting to occupy oneself with the good mind, and speaking the goodness to many people, those are called sleep. Fear (<foreign>bhaya</foreign>) means being afraid to ask for oneself, being afraid to ask because he feels senior, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> being afraid to speak goodness, those are called fear. Laziness (<foreign>tandrī</foreign>) means being lazy to ask because he feels ignorant, being lazy to act with a joyful mind, and to speak of goodness to many people, those are called laziness. Irresolution (<foreign>kleda</foreign>) means being hesitant to act with good mind to the people, being hesitant to ask about oneself, those are called irresolution. Shame (<foreign>lajjā</foreign>) means he finds it difficult to to ask because he feels stupid, he finds it difficult to render service because he feels senior, he finds it difficult to render service because he feels rich. Lust of women (<foreign>rāgastrī</foreign>) means being keen on desiring to have an intercourse and wish to be rich, <supplied reason="subaudible">those</supplied> are called lust of women. Adultery (<foreign>paradāra</foreign>) means desiring a widowed girl, the forbidden woman of other people, those are called adultery. Eating the food (<foreign>bhakṣabhojāna</foreign>) means he does not do the goodness; that is bhakṣabhojāna, namely, always eating, always drinking, †<foreign>dəṅ hjə</foreign>†,<note>I cannot reconstruct <foreign>dəṅ hjə</foreign>. Probably it should emend to <foreign>dəṅ həjən</foreign>, in the light of MdS <foreign>heujeun</foreign> ‘bowel motion’, in the sense of someone who is being too full? </note> for his desire being fulfilled by the six tastes (<foreign>ṣaḍrasa</foreign>), those are called eating the food. Dishonest consideration (<foreign>kuṭilaviveka</foreign>) means to postpone to act with joyful mind and to speak the goodness to the people. Those are called the ten stains, according to the learned master.</p></div>
.<div n="7" corresp="#smg_07"><p corresp="#smg_07.01">Again, the following are called the ten hells (<foreign>dasa-naraka</foreign>). This is its manifestations: ears, eyes, nose, tongue, mouth, skin, hand, anus, genital, feet.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.02">The meaning is: the ears<note>I interpret <foreign>taliṅa</foreign> as ‘ear’, following the meaning in OJ. This word rarely appears in OS, but is very productive in SMG. The meaning in other OS texts is unclear because it only appears as the name of a god: <foreign>taliṅa jati</foreign> (KaPaṅ 321). In MdS, <foreign>talinga</foreign> means ‘to watch’. In this paragraph, the author uses both OS <foreign>cəli</foreign> and OJ <foreign>taliṅa</foreign>.</note> should not hear wrongly, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> quickly react<note>I consider <foreign>vaṅvaṅ</foreign> as an equivalent of OJ <foreign>vavaṅ</foreign> ‘directly, at once, straight away, forthwith’. However, I wonder whether it could be related to OS <foreign>humarivaṅvaṅ</foreign> ‘be worry’ = MdS <foreign>hariwang</foreign> ‘apprehensive, anxious, concerned, worried’?</note> when hearing <supplied reason="subaudible">something</supplied>. The consequences are: having imperfect hearing (<foreign>havar</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>havar</foreign> is not recorded in MdS as an ear disease. In MdS, its reduplicated form <foreign>hawar-hawar</foreign> means ‘faintly audible (sometimes: visible), vague (of sounds coming from afar, also fig. of rumors etc.); (of so. ’s hearing) vague, indistinct, unclear’.</note> purulent ear (<foreign>coṅe</foreign>), deafness, <foreign>cadaṅ</foreign>,<note>The word <foreign>cadaṅ</foreign> is unclear and is not found in the dictionaries. Probably related to Mal. <foreign>radang</foreign> ‘disease in severe form’?</note> those would be the miseries of the ears.</p>
1960<p corresp="#smg_07.03">The eyes should not look wantonly, for instance the widow of someone else, the forbidden woman of someone else, if they are not ours. The consequences are: being blind in one eye (<foreign>pecak</foreign>), poor eyesight (<foreign>bolor</foreign>), <foreign>putikən</foreign>,<note>The word <foreign>putikən</foreign> is not recorded in MdS. This word is also attested in OJ SHK in the same meaning: <foreign>kadyaṅgān ikanaṅ vvaṅ lara matan putikən, ramun matanya</foreign> “like a man, whose eye is afflicted by <foreign>putikən</foreign>”. Probably related to Mal. <foreign>putik</foreign> ‘<foreign>buah yang masih muda dan kecil</foreign>’ (fruit that is still young and small) (Kamus Dewan, s.v.)?</note> white spot in the eye (<foreign>ceaṅ</foreign>), color-blindness (<foreign>buta loroṅən</foreign>),<note>The disease <foreign>buta loroṅən</foreign> seems to be an equivalent with <foreign>buta rorongeun</foreign> in MdS. It is a kind of eye disease. Danadibrata defines <foreign>buta rorongeun</foreign> as ‘teu bisa ngabédakeun warna’ (can not differentiate the color) = Mal. <foreign>buta warna</foreign>.’ Dadan Sutisna showed me an earlier publication in the 20th century, that <foreign>buta rorongeun</foreign> refers to the person who is incapable of seeing during the night, but I am inclined to interpret it as color-blind in this context, since we have <foreign>mata kotokən</foreign> for night-blindness. Cf. SMG 14.2.</note> night-blindness (<foreign>mata kotokən</foreign>), <foreign>bilas susuhən</foreign>,<note><foreign>bilas susuhən</foreign>: <foreign>susuh</foreign> is a kind of freshwater snail (lime is burned from the shells) (Hardjadibrata, s.v), while <foreign>bilas</foreign> in MdS only attested in the form <foreign>bibilas</foreign> ‘dessert’, probably the basic meaning is ‘to wash’, cf. Mal. <foreign>cuci mulut</foreign>. The relation between ‘wash’ and a kind of snail is strange. I am inclined to relate <foreign>bilas</foreign> with MdS <foreign>balas</foreign> ‘parasitic growth on the skin, cyst, outgrowth (three types are distinguished: <foreign>balas bogo</foreign>, <foreign>balas bulé</foreign>, <foreign>balas reunghas</foreign>); <foreign>babalasan</foreign> s.m.; (also) name of destructive rice-plant disease.’ From the context, I guess we should relate it with a kind of eye disease that resembles a snail?</note> those would be the miseries of the eyes.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.04">The nose reacts quickly to all kinds of smell. If <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> smells stink, mouldy smell, rancid, burning smell, those provoke him to sneeze,<note>The word <foreign>bumarəsin</foreign> is only attested in SMG, the possible base word is <foreign>barəsin</foreign>, which seems related to MdS <foreign>bersin</foreign> ‘to sneeze’, also in Malay ‘id.’.</note> to blow the nose (?, <foreign>ṅahubus</foreign>).<note>The meaning of <foreign>ṅahubus</foreign> ‘to blow the nose’ is a guess. This word is found nowhere in dictionaries, but it seems to be related to MdS <foreign>ngahébos</foreign> ‘struck against somewhere (in an outbreak of flames, heat radiation of a striking thunder flash or exploding gas, the hot breath of a demon, etc.)’ or Mal. <foreign>(h)embus</foreign> ‘to blow’.</note> The consequence is <foreign>mekmek</foreign>, that would be the misery of the nose.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.05">The tongue reacts quickly to all kinds of tastes. When <supplied reason="subaudible">it tastes the flavor of</supplied> stale, cold, foul-smelling, acidic, spicy, salty, it is used to taste everything (? <foreign>usuh-asahan</foreign>).<note>The meaning of reduplication with suffix <foreign>usuh-asahan</foreign> is obscure. My interpretation is based on the phonological resemblance with MdS <foreign>asa</foreign> ‘to taste’.</note> The consequences are: mute, tongue defect (?, <foreign>petal</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>petal</foreign> is unrecorded in dictionaries. Probably it is synonymous with <foreign>cadel</foreign> ‘lisp’?</note> lisp, all of those would be the miseries of the tongue.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.06">The mouth is used to gripe, only to be used to talk and whine,<note>We find a base word <foreign>kumapang</foreign> in MdS, which means ‘talk while crying’. It seems that the base is <foreign>kapaṅ</foreign>. The reduplicated form <foreign>kumapaṅ-kapaṅ</foreign> seems to mean ‘talk and whine’.</note> and also to be used for cursing and blaming, inviting others to do deceitful <supplied reason="subaudible">acts</supplied>.<note>I interpret <foreign>ṅajak ṅapus</foreign> as ‘inviting others to do deceitful acts’; cf. OJ <foreign>aṅapus</foreign> ‘to deceive’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>apus</foreign>, <foreign>aṅapus</foreign> 4).</note> The consequences are: harelips, wry lips, open mouth disease (?, <foreign>dəda</foreign>),<note>The meaning of <foreign>dəda</foreign> is dubious. I relate this word to Mal. <foreign>dedah</foreign> ‘exposed, opened, reveal’ but the meaning in the context of disease remains obscure.</note> those would be the miseries of the mouth.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.07">The skin is used to touch wantonly. If it is affected by hot, cold, itchy, tingling, <supplied reason="subaudible">then</supplied> it is tossed and turned. The consequences are: malignant boil (<foreign>tibar</foreign>), boil (<foreign>bisul</foreign>), foot-sole skin disorder (<foreign>boloṅən</foreign>), skin rash (<foreign>radaṅ</foreign>), smallpox (<foreign>kuris</foreign>), reddish skin (<foreign>beaṅ</foreign>),<note>The word <foreign>beaṅ</foreign> ‘reddish skin’ is equivalent to OJ <foreign>vyaṅ</foreign> ‘reddish colour’. Cf. the expression MdS <foreign>biang karinget</foreign>, also Mal. <foreign>biang keringat</foreign>.</note> including cyste (<foreign>balas</foreign>) <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> itchy skin eruption (<foreign>galigata</foreign>), those would be the miseries of the skin.</p>
1965<p corresp="#smg_07.08">The hand is used to grab wantonly, especially the property of others, the plants of others.<note>The preposition <foreign>ka</foreign> in <foreign>ka tatanəman</foreign> seems to indicate the direct object, because of the verb with motion <foreign>cokot</foreign> ‘to take’. We find several cases where the transitive verb of motion is followed by the preposition which functions to be the mark of a direct object, such as <foreign>ṅala</foreign> ‘to take, to collect’.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> also used to clench the fist, to stab, to knock, to clasp, to slap, to pull hair, to pinch, to lash (?, <foreign>ṅagətil</foreign>).<note>The word <foreign>gətil</foreign> is probably related to MdS <foreign>gitik</foreign> ‘hit so./an animal (with a cane, whip, etc.), lash, whip; strike (the cymbals); impose st. on so. (a fine or a sentence); <foreign>ngagitikkeun</foreign> a. strike so. with st. (a cane etc.)’, or is it related to Mal. <foreign>sentil</foreign> ‘to flick’?</note> The consequences are bent fingers, arms that are stiff, cut off, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> difficult to move. Those would be the miseries of the hand.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.09">The anus<note>In MdS, <foreign>tumbung</foreign> means ‘germinating hole of a coconut; mouth of the vagina’. Rigg (1864) notes an interesting explanation: “<foreign>Tumbung</foreign>, pudendum muliebre. In Malay <foreign>Tumbung</foreign> means: the seed of plants, evidently from <foreign>Tumbu</foreign>, to shoot up. Thus the Sunda word will literally convey the idea of the place whence the human race springs. In Malay also Crawfurd gives Tumbung, <foreign>prolapsus uteri vel ani</foreign>. The final <foreign>ng</foreign> thus modifies the sense a little. <foreign>Tumbong</foreign> in Malay also, Marsden, page 81, is a hole in the surface of anything hollow; a vent or spile-hole; <foreign>the anus</foreign>. <foreign>Tumbong kalapa</foreign>, the hole in a cocoa-nut from whence it sprouts”. Not in OJ.</note> is used to fart wantonly, to defecate wherever one wants, on the side yard of somebody else’s house, let alone let off a fart against someone. The consequences are constipation (?, <foreign>kabəratan</foreign>),<note><foreign>kabəratan</foreign>: in MdS, one of the meaning of <foreign>kabeuratan</foreign> is ‘to defecate’, it is a <foreign>lemes</foreign> register of <foreign>ngising</foreign>. My tentative interpretation ‘constipation’ is based on the context.</note> diarrhea (<foreign>tuju pañcar</foreign>),<note>I interpret <foreign>tuju pañcar</foreign> as diarrhea, based on the connection of <foreign>tuju</foreign> and <foreign>pancer</foreign> in MdS. In MdS, <foreign>tuju</foreign> means ‘(as the first member in the popular name of certain mostly connected with magically caused-sickness or afflictions); <foreign>tuju deleg</foreign> (O.) sickness that comes out in stomach pain and an inclination to vomit; <foreign>tuju rancah</foreign> s.m. fluid loss shortly before giving birth; (O. also mentioned: <foreign>tuju rawayan</foreign>, <foreign>tuju roroké</foreign>)’. The word <foreign>pañcar</foreign> seems to be equivalent to MdS <foreign>pancer</foreign> ‘cascading, shoot out’.</note> bleeding anus (<foreign>kaliṅsir</foreign>), sediment (?, <foreign>uirən</foreign>).<note><foreign>uirən</foreign>: in MdS, <foreign>uwir</foreign> means ‘torn piece (of paper, material, etc.); short note (accompanying letter, temporary license in lieu of the original, et.); <foreign>sauwir</foreign> a (torn) piece, etc., a leaf of paper’; cf. MdS <foreign>cewir</foreign>, <foreign>ewir</foreign> ‘id.’. In the context of stomach disease, probably it refers to urine sediment, but it remains a hypothesis.</note> Those would be the miseries of the anus.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.10">The genitals are used to pee wherever one wants. They are also used to seek boys and girls, transgress with younger siblings, elder siblings, children of younger siblings (<foreign>suan</foreign>), children of elder siblings (<foreign>kaponakan</foreign>). The consequences are hernia (<foreign>burut</foreign>), deformed <supplied reason="subaudible">genitals</supplied> (<foreign>petot</foreign>), <foreign>lañjo</foreign> (?),<note>The meaning of <foreign>lañjo</foreign> is unclear, but it is attested in OJ among the kinds of defects or diseases. Cf. Kuñj 63.19: <foreign>kəḍi, kumiṅ, lañjo, kasesih, ayan, edan</foreign>. This context makes clear that it refers to a kind of genital disease. However, in MdS the similar word <foreign>lanjung</foreign> meand ‘light in the head, dizzy, giddy, confused’.</note> impaired sexual desire (<foreign>halaṅ visaya</foreign>), impotence (<foreign>pəluh</foreign>). Those would be the miseries of the genitals.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.11">The feet are used to step wantonly, to walk carelessly, for instance when you walk to the north, south, west, east; if the feet happen to stumble, bump, or if they are used to kick. The consequences are weak feet (?, <foreign>lisuh</foreign>),<note>The translation of <foreign>lisuh</foreign> as ‘weak feet’ is tentative. I interpret this word as an equivalent of MdS <foreign>lusuh</foreign> ‘decreased, diminished, lessen, decline (of physical strength)’.</note> broken <supplied reason="subaudible">feet</supplied>, dog-like feet (?, <foreign>añjiṅən</foreign>), feet with outgrowth (?, <foreign>caniran</foreign>).<note>In MdS, <foreign>canir</foreign> means ‘buttress (boardshaped running outgrowth below the trunk of certain trees like the canary and ficus etc.; of which disc-wheels were made in the past)’. I guess that <foreign>caniran</foreign> refers to a kind of foot disease like a <foreign>plantar fibroma</foreign> (a fibrous knot, or nodule, in the arch of the foot).</note> Those would be the miseries of the feet.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_07.12">Thus are what are called the ten hells. The servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should pay attention, those <supplied reason="subaudible">actions</supplied> should not be followed.</p></div>
1970<div n="8" corresp="#smg_08"><p corresp="#smg_08.01">As follows are the five objects of attention. How so? The verse is as follows:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_08.02">“Non-anger, obedience to the teacher, purity, moderation in food, and non-inattentiveness are the five well known as particular commandments.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_08.03">The meaning is: <foreign>akrodho</foreign> means it does not happen to the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>, that he shows his anger in front of the elder (teacher), let alone in front of all people. <foreign>Āhāralāghavam</foreign> means being unhurried<note>I render <foreign>sumari</foreign> to mean ‘to wait, to postpone, unhurried, leisurely, passing away the time with’ according to the meaning in OJ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>sari</foreign>), not in MdS.</note> in making preparations<note>My interpretation of <foreign>sumarəmbah</foreign> ‘to make preparation’ is based on an attested word in OJ <foreign>sārəmbha</foreign> (from Skt. <foreign>sārambha</foreign> ‘having made a beginning, ready to start, preparatory’). The term <foreign>āhāralāghavam</foreign> is related to the meal or food, so it seems that this is the meaning in this context. </note> for <supplied reason="subaudible">the meal</supplied>; it is improper to eat and to drink in front of the scholar. <foreign>Apramādas ca pañca vaite</foreign> means when there is something needed<note>The word <foreign>dipikən</foreign> seems to mean ‘to be intended, to be needed’, from <foreign>pikən</foreign> ‘intended for’. Cf. <foreign>piənan</foreign> in SMG 4.1.</note> by others, his attitude follows the one who is short-tempered and surly: one doesn’t want to think about oneself, and does not want to seek what will bring goodness <supplied reason="subaudible">for oneself only</supplied>. Those are called the five objects of attention.</p></div>
.<div n="9" corresp="#smg_09"><p corresp="#smg_09.01">As follow are called the four means, as follows is the meaning:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_09.02">“Writing, laughing, singing, yawning, and pure <supplied reason="subaudible">from</supplied> the secret of fruit (?), shall not do in the front of the teacher”</p>
1975<p corresp="#smg_09.03">The meaning is: <foreign>ālekhyam</foreign> means it is improper if we scratch the ground, to write the board <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> the couch in front of the teacher. <foreign>Hasitam</foreign> means it is improper to laugh when starting <supplied reason="subaudible">activity</supplied> in front of the teacher, and also to play around<note><foreign>ñiar pikaulinanən</foreign> ‘to play around’, literally means ‘look for things to play’. The circumfix <foreign>pi- -ən</foreign> from the secondary <foreign>ka- -an</foreign> in <foreign>pikaulinanən</foreign> form is rather rare in OS, but it is attested in SMG, for instance, <foreign>pikabuyutanən</foreign>.</note> in front of the scholar <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> in front of all people. <foreign>Gītam</foreign> means not singing <foreign>kiduṅ</foreign>, <foreign>kavih</foreign>,<note>I consider <foreign>kiduṅ</foreign> and <foreign>kavih</foreign> as two distinguished method of singing. See chapter 4, §Genres.</note> to sing loudly, let alone to claim oneself skilled, expert, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> wise in front of people. <foreign>Jr̥mbhanam</foreign> means it is improper to declare oneself thirsty and hungry, even though one is excessively full in front of the scholar, let alone of all people. <foreign>Kaṇṭhāravāñ</foreign> means, it is improper if we call <supplied reason="subaudible">someone</supplied> out loud, and also to stretch oneself in front of the people. <foreign>Śuddham</foreign> means it is improper if the mind and speech are disturbing<note>For the interpretation of <foreign>hura-hura</foreign>, cf. OJ <foreign>vurah</foreign> and <foreign>hurah</foreign>, in which their derivatives <foreign>mavurahan</foreign>, <foreign>ahurahan</foreign>, <foreign>pavurahan</foreign> mean ‘tumultuous, with a confused noise and/or motion’. Cf. Malay <foreign>hura-hara</foreign> ‘disturbance’ and later development <foreign>huru-hara</foreign>. Another meaning of <foreign>hura-hura</foreign> in Malay is ‘having a good time, happy’, also ‘party’ which seems unlikely in this context.</note> and false. <foreign>Phalarahasyam</foreign> means it is improper to mention the genitals<note>In MdS, <foreign>bobogaan</foreign> literally means ‘(various) things that some one possess, possessions (collect.)’, but also an euphemism for ‘genitals or private parts’.</note> of others. <foreign>Na karotu gurumukhe</foreign> means, it is improper if our mind and speech are careless (?, <foreign>rumagodeh</foreign>)<note>The interpretation of <foreign>rumagodeh</foreign> as ‘careless’ is a conjecture based on context, also by taking into account the phonological resemblance to MdS <foreign>lalawodéh</foreign> ‘careless, casual, off-hand (when working)’.</note> in front of the scholar. These are called the four means. The servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should pay attention, <supplied reason="subaudible">those actions</supplied> should not be followed.</p></div>
.<div n="10" corresp="#smg_10"><p corresp="#smg_10.01">The following are called the five explanations. As follows is the verse:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_10.02"><foreign>selajanəm suravile, panatargasudya ceva, prayagamanəm, cevamasva cevamibuh, karmavidu, cevayude, danakaləm ma suprəgrahaste</foreign>.<note>10.1 I cannot reconstruct the Sanskrit stanzas in this <foreign>śloka</foreign>. The readings of SMG ms. A as well as manuscripts containing SiGu are corrupted in this part.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_10.03">The meaning is: <foreign>selajanəm</foreign> means to be indifferent and denying when talking and deliberating in front of the elder <supplied reason="subaudible">teacher</supplied>. <foreign>Suravile</foreign> means to be indifferent: especially when talking and deliberating, one does not apply good manners towards the scholar. Also, it is improper to use powders that are smelled by a lot of people, or <supplied reason="subaudible">when one</supplied> welcomes (<foreign>asvagatah kunaṅ</foreign>) <supplied reason="subaudible">them</supplied>. <foreign>Panatarga</foreign> means it is improper to brush teeth and to show teeth in front of people.<note>On the word <foreign>masaṅgereṅ</foreign>, cf. MdS <foreign>nyanggéréng</foreign> (from <foreign>sanggéréng</foreign>) ‘show clearly (the teeth of man or animal)’. It is noteworthy that <foreign>masanggéréng</foreign> (prefix <foreign>ma</foreign>- + <foreign>sanggéréng</foreign>) does not exist in MdS.</note> <foreign>Sudyacava</foreign> means it is improper to imitate the play of actors (<foreign>həmpul</foreign>) and buffoons (<foreign>mirus</foreign>). <foreign>Prayāsamāgama</foreign> means, it is improper if we stare at each other with other people, let alone to be face to face, to be face to face with the elders staring at each other, also to claim <supplied reason="subaudible">to have been</supplied> eating and drinking in front of people. <foreign>Ceva masvateh</foreign> means having wrong minds and intentions towards fellow humans. <foreign>Ceva mibuh</foreign> means having bad appearance, bad behaviors, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> not following advice. <foreign>Karmavidu</foreign> means having a wrinkled face,<note>The word <foreign>kəsit</foreign> means ‘quick’ in MdS (cf. Mal. <foreign>gesit</foreign>), but does not seem to fit the context. Probably the meaning is ‘wrinkled (of face)’ (s.m. MdS <foreign>kusut</foreign>), a quasi-synonym of <foreign>tuṅi</foreign> ‘aloof, standoffish, surly, unfriendly’ = MdS <foreign>tungi</foreign>. Cf. one of the meanings of <foreign>kesit</foreign> in Mal. ‘<foreign>berkerut (tentang kulit tubuh dan sebagainya)</foreign> (wrinkled (about skin etc.)’.</note> being surly, wry-faced, sullen, <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> frowning<note>The word <foreign>baruṅut</foreign> is a hapax, my interpretation is based on a similar word in MdS <foreign>berengut</foreign> ‘frowning, gruff (of facial expression), surly, grumpy, churlish, ill-mannered’.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">when</supplied> interacting with people. <foreign>Ceva yude</foreign> means having a bad appearance, bad behaviors, bad results,<note>The interpretation of <foreign>pupuna</foreign> as ‘his result’ is a guess. I take it from the verbal <foreign>mupu</foreign> ‘to collect, to take’, and a substantive form <foreign>pupu</foreign> is expected to have a meaning ‘result, something to be taken’. Or should it be emend to <foreign>pupulihna</foreign> ‘his words’?</note> those are called the lowest among people. <foreign>Ceva yude</foreign> means beset with troubles<note>The word <foreign>suraṅ</foreign> is not found in MdS and OJ. However, MdJ has <foreign>surang</foreign> ‘beset with troubles’ which is suitable to the context.</note> by making a joke, being fond of playing with <foreign>pariambul</foreign> words toward others. <foreign>Danakaləm</foreign> means not willingly helping, having compassion, and love to fellow human beings. The mind is full of hate. <foreign>Suprigrəhasta</foreign> means having too much desire, talking about our intention, bring it to the discussion wishing to realize it quickly, although it will not be achieved. Those are called the five explanations (<foreign>pañca-byakta</foreign>), those <supplied reason="subaudible">actions</supplied> should not be followed, 5.</p></div>
.<div n="11" corresp="#smg_11"><p corresp="#smg_11.01">As follows are called the four devotions (<foreign>catur-paṅabakti</foreign>). The verses are as follows:</p>
1980<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_11.02">“<supplied reason="subaudible">Through which</supplied> bad luck is left behind, having bowed down to the Lord of the Universe, I will recite the foot sole of the teacher.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_11.03">The meaning is: <foreign>gurutalam</foreign> means it is improper to speak and converse in haste in front of the scholar. <foreign>Pravakṣyāmi</foreign> means it is improper to talk about righteousness in front of the scholar, also in front of people, especially <supplied reason="subaudible">in front</supplied> of mother, father, and teachers. <foreign>Mahāyānam</foreign> means that one forgets to think about oneself. <foreign>Hi tiṣṭhati</foreign> means it is improper if we look at the elders with arrogance. <foreign>Durbhagahīne sarveśaṁ</foreign> means that one forgets what is in front of him, does not think of things which bring goodness. <foreign>Griyapa praṇamyāsīt</foreign> means one wish to quickly get rich and have everything,<note>My interpretation of <foreign>vaya-vaya</foreign> as ‘have everything’ is based on the context. Cf. Mal. idiom <foreign>orang berada</foreign> (from the base <foreign>ada</foreign> = OS <foreign>vaya</foreign>), denoting ‘the rich people’.</note> i.e. to have servants, subordinates,<note>The word <foreign>kuriṅ</foreign> ‘servant, slave’, also spelled <foreign>kuri</foreign> in some OS texts. It is noteworthy that In MdS <foreign>kuring</foreign> is a 1st singular pronoun, but the meaning ‘servant’ is not attested in MdS. This word is unattested in OJ.</note> workers, and livestock, and yet this <supplied reason="subaudible">wish</supplied> is not fulfilled. Those are called the four devotions, as told by the scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="12" corresp="#smg_12"><p corresp="#smg_12.01">As follows are called the five objects of attention (<foreign>pañca-prayatna</foreign>). The verse is as follows:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_12.02"><foreign>hīnavākyam siṅharupañ ca grahaste</foreign> | <foreign>gurusaṅghāsanam prətanəm</foreign>, <foreign>grəhaste nāmani mate</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_12.03">The meaning is: <foreign>hīnavākyam</foreign> means it is improper to speak of goodness, to teach in front of the elder <supplied reason="subaudible">teacher</supplied>. <foreign>Siṅharupañ ca grahaste</foreign> means it is improper that we are seen angry by the elders and <supplied reason="subaudible">showing</supplied> dislike. <foreign>Guru saṅgasanəm prītam</foreign> means it is improper if we <supplied reason="subaudible">shot that we</supplied> are happy, frolicking, joyful and pleased<note>I consider <foreign>grəjita</foreign> to be equivalent to OJ <foreign>garjita</foreign> ‘delighted, joyful, pleased, elated.’ (OJED, s.v.), from Skt. <foreign>garjita</foreign> ‘sounded, roared, bellowed; boasted, swaggered, vaunted’.</note> when we are on the street, <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> when we go to the forest to take trees and leaves, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> we sit there with legs wide,<note>The verb <foreign>ṅaduṅkak</foreign> seems to be equivalent with MdS <foreign>ngadéngkak</foreign> ‘spread the legs wide, sit straddling, sit with legs wide apart (like sitting on horseback, also of children carried on the hip: one leg at the front and one leg at the back)’. MdS has <foreign>dungkak-déngkak</foreign>, considered that <foreign>déngkak</foreign> is the base of intervocalic reduplication <foreign>dungkak-déngkak</foreign>, but in OS we find that the base <foreign>duṅkak</foreign> has an active form.</note> then we are seen by the scholar. Also, it is unpleasant for us <supplied reason="subaudible">to be</supplied> ahead in walking, and to be in the shadow of the elders.<note>The interpretation of <foreign>maṅka dinapak maya</foreign> as ‘to be in the shadow of’ is reasonably clear from the context. However, the verbal form <foreign>dinapak</foreign> is unusual since the prefix <foreign>di-</foreign> in OS and MdS is intransitive. It is clearly a translation of <foreign>anapak maya</foreign> in SiGu 5.3. Another possibility is to emend this phrase to <foreign>makadi napak maya</foreign>, but the conjunction <foreign>makadi</foreign> is extremely rare in OS. It is only attested in Kebantenan inscriptions.</note> <foreign>Prətanəm</foreign> means it is <!-- until here 23 february from gdoc--> improper to smell the food of the teacher, let alone to use the utensils of the scholar, to take marked properties (<foreign>savenan</foreign>), and to take stored <supplied reason="subaudible">properties</supplied>. <foreign>Grəhaste namaniṅ mate</foreign> means it is improper to mention the name of mother, father, as well as the teacher, and especially the elders, not to mention the name of king, village elders, hermits, ritual experts (<foreign>disi</foreign>), and sailors (<foreign>tarahan</foreign>). Those are called the five objects of attention (<foreign>pañca-prayatna</foreign>), according the scholar.</p></div>
1985<div n="13" corresp="#smg_13"><p corresp="#smg_13.01">The following are called three elements (<foreign>tri-buta</foreign>). These are the explanations: bad meets its bad,<note>On the word <foreign>goce</foreign>, cf. MdS <foreign>goté</foreign> ‘(coarse word for) bad; see <foreign>goréng</foreign>., but some dialects have <foreign>goté</foreign> ‘ugly’.</note> crooked meets its crooked, misery meets its misery.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_13.02">The meaning is: <foreign>hala</foreign> means bad; that the outcome<note>I interpret <foreign>pisampakən</foreign> as ‘outcome, what will be available or present’, from <foreign>sampak</foreign> ‘to be present’.</note> is bad because what has been practiced is bad. <foreign>Vilut</foreign> means crooked: that the outcome is crooked because what has been practiced is crooked. <foreign>Duka</foreign> means terrified: that the outcome is terrifying because what has been practiced is terrifying. Those are called the three elements. The servants of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should pay attention, those <supplied reason="subaudible">actions</supplied> should not be followed.</p></div>
.<div n="14" corresp="#smg_14"><p corresp="#smg_14.01">As follows are called the four pacifiers (<foreign>catur-pasanta</foreign>). The following are its explanations: the formula of <foreign>jalakuna</foreign>, the formula of <foreign>jalapaksa</foreign>, the formula of <foreign>sambarana</foreign>, the formula of <foreign>taraṅgabahu</foreign>.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_14.02">The formula of <foreign>jalakuna</foreign> is the sun. Things which cause miseries to the body are: weak vision, monocular blindness, bilas, eye disease, color blindness, night blindness, dazzlement.<note>My interpretation of <foreign>hulap</foreign> ‘dazzlement’ is based on its meaning in OJ. This word is not recorded in MdS.</note> The formula of <foreign>jalapaksa</foreign> is the water. Things which cause miseries to the body are shivering<note><foreign>gumigil</foreign>: the word <foreign>gigil</foreign> is not found in MdS. The meaning ‘shivering’ is taken from OJ <foreign>gumigil</foreign> ‘ague, a fever’. Cf. Mal. <foreign>menggigil</foreign> ‘id.’.</note> and chills. The formula of <foreign>sambarana</foreign> is the wind. Things which cause miseries to the body are reddish skin, skin eruptions, skin fungal disease (?, <foreign>pipisisan</foreign>), every kind of skin disease. The formula of <foreign>taraṅgabahu</foreign> is the mountain. Things which cause miseries to the body are: headache, stomach ache, abdominal distention (<foreign>mədu</foreign>), abscess of the liver (<foreign>kavayaan</foreign>), every kind of disease in the stomach. Those are called the four pacifiers, that should be made of attention by the servant of the dharma, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> should not be kept secret.</p></div>
.<div n="15" corresp="#smg_15"><p corresp="#smg_15.01">As follows are called the five misfortunes. These are the explanations: sorrow from the elements, sorrow from gods, sorrow from three worlds.</p>
1990<p corresp="#smg_15.02">The sorrows from the elements are: died from being bitten by the snake, being struck by lightning, bitten by the crocodile, crushed by branches, devoured by the tiger, death in battle, intercepted, attacked by many <supplied reason="subaudible">enemies</supplied>, died of falling <supplied reason="subaudible">from above</supplied>, <supplied reason="subaudible">by</supplied> all kinds of weapons in the battle. That is called the sorrow from the elements.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_15.03">The sorrows from the gods are: diarrhea (<foreign>tajam bətəṅ</foreign>), cold shivers, headache, sore eyes, <foreign>jaroṅ</foreign>-like disease,<note>See my comment on <foreign>jaroṅən</foreign> in SiGu 13.2.</note> <foreign>sumbilaṅ</foreign>-like disease,<note>See my comment on <foreign>sumbilaṅən</foreign> in SiGu 13.2.</note> madness, abdominal distention, fever. Those are called the sorrow from the gods.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_15.04">The sorrows from the body are: monocular blindness, cleft lip, crippled, blind, deaf, rash, cut (off ears?, <foreign>rumpuṅ</foreign>), cut off <supplied reason="subaudible">limbs</supplied>. Those are called the sorrow of the body. As for what is called the sorrow of the three worlds are all kinds <supplied reason="subaudible">of persons</supplied> who are affected by misfortune in the world.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_15.05">These are the examples of those who are affected by the miseries: kings, elders, hermits, ritualists, and sailors, for in the <foreign>kali</foreign>’s era, they are the roots of the sins that lead to suffering (i.e., hell), <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> become: the demon Kāla, the dogs called Jamproṅ and Karavəlaṅ; <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> become a pair of cauldrons, strips of iron lances and spikes, in the village of destination, slanting plank bridge, <foreign>vajra</foreign>’s coconut (i.e, sugar palm?), the dirty mud, standing aslant branches, clutching rocks, the <foreign>rayang-rayang</foreign> called Prəca Kala and Prəca Kali, — <supplied reason="subaudible">also</supplied> the dissention and seduction (?, <foreign>beda bañcana</foreign>), a creation expert,<note>This word <foreign>siptaguna</foreign> appears twice in this paragraph: first it is applied to the goldsmith, and second to the carpenter. The meaning remains obscure since <foreign>sipta</foreign> is an unknown word. Tentatively, I relate this word with <foreign>cipta</foreign>, which means ‘to focus the thoughts on, to be of the opinion that; esp. to cause something to appear by focussing one’s thought on it’. However, in the present context, <foreign>sipta</foreign> seems to mean ‘to create, to design’ as in the MdS sense of <foreign>cipta</foreign>. The change of /c/ to /s/ also occurs in the case of OS <foreign>isəs</foreign> &gt; MdS <foreign>iceus</foreign>.</note> an iron expert, a banner expert,<note><foreign>patakaguna</foreign>: I interpret <foreign>pataka</foreign> as ‘flag, pennon, banner, sign’ according to the OJ meaning (OJED, s.v. <foreign>patāka</foreign>) The common meaning of <foreign>pataka</foreign> is ‘dissaster, misfortune’.</note> an image expert, a child (play?) expert.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_15.06">The meaning is precisely as follows: the balancing (?, <foreign>samya</foreign>) expert is the bracelet smith, the creation (?, <foreign>sipta</foreign>) expert is the goldsmith, the iron expert is the blacksmith, the banner expert is the cloth painter (? <foreign>pamadək</foreign>), the plant expert is the cultivator (<foreign>pahuma</foreign>), the creation expert is the carpenter, the composition expert is the actor (<foreign>həmpul</foreign>), the childsplay (? <foreign>kumara</foreign>) expert is the performer, the kala is the king’s servant, <supplied reason="subaudible">the dogs</supplied> called Jampong and Karawélang are <foreign>barat katiga</foreign>;<note><foreign>barat katiga</foreign>: in OJ, this word means ‘a strong wind in the third month’. Zoetmulder records its derived form <foreign>ambarat katiga</foreign> ‘like a strong wind in the third month’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>barat</foreign>). This combination is also listed among military functionaries in Pdg 5.5 <foreign>ṅūni-ṅūni taṅ binoroṅ, sinəlir mvaṅ tinonton, vaju kuniṅ, vahuta, parujar, praleki, untal-untal, barat katiga, ṅuniveh popoṇṭaṅ bhayaṅkara, popoṅo, vadvā barat</foreign> “let alone those who “are encouraged”, those who are picked and those who are watched [as they give performances?], the [wearers of] yellow garments, the <foreign>vahuta</foreign> officials, the spokesmen (?), the <foreign>pralekis</foreign>, the <foreign>untal-untal</foreign>s, the three <foreign>barat</foreign>s (soldiers?), and also the <foreign>popoṇṭaṅ</foreign> soldiers of the royal guard, the <foreign>popoṅo</foreign>s, the troops of the West (?)”. Cf. SKK 7.3.</note> the female animals (or prostitutes ? <foreign>rayang-rayang</foreign>) are those without a name, the dissention and seduction <supplied reason="subaudible">expert</supplied> is the merchant, the wide moor is the <foreign>ləbuh</foreign>, <foreign>salaksi loñana</foreign> is the hunter, the end of the moon is the <foreign>prəjala</foreign>, a sinful man is the gambler, a stained man is the servant (<foreign>dasa</foreign>); the one who accepts in marriage is the <foreign>calagara</foreign>, the one who extracts is the collector (<foreign>paṅuraṅ</foreign>),<note>On the clauses <foreign>voṅ papa ma nu bobotoh, voṅ kalesa ma na dasa, si manarema ma, calagara, si manarek ma, na paṅuraṅ</foreign>, see Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths 2021: 162–164.</note> the standing branch is the provider (?, <foreign>parada</foreign>), the destination village is the helper (?, <foreign>kasasa</foreign>),<note>Cf. RR 234–235 where <foreign>kasasa</foreign> occurs along with <foreign>bayaṅkara</foreign>: <foreign>kasasa dəṅ bayaṅkara, juru tombak jati ləpas</foreign>. See also <foreign>diasa</foreign> in SKK 4.13. In this case, <foreign>kasasa</foreign> probably means ‘(military) servants’. Cf. SKK 7.3.</note> the slanting plank bridge is the <foreign>paməəṅ</foreign>,<note>The expected base form of <foreign>paməəṅ</foreign> is <foreign>pəəṅ</foreign>, which in MdS <foreign>peueung</foreign> means ‘n. a very low tree, Dichrostachys cinerea W. et A., member of the Leguminosae (the very hard and strong wood is used a.o. as bows, the peas are used as medicine to get rid of worms; also called: <foreign>pung</foreign>); 2. palm wine (R)’. The first meaning is probably close to the meaning that we expect here, but I do not know if such a tree was used for making bridges.</note> the sugar palm<note>The term <foreign>kalapa bajra</foreign> literally means the ‘iron/steel coconut’. On the term <foreign>bajra</foreign> as steel, see my comment on <foreign>bajra-pañjara</foreign> in SKK 11.21. My interpretation of it as ‘sugar palm’ is based on the obvious meaning of <foreign>pañadap</foreign> ‘tapper’.</note> is the tapper (<foreign>pañadap</foreign>), the dirty mud<note>15.6 On <foreign>latak</foreign> ‘mud’, cf. OJ <foreign>latək</foreign> and MdS <foreign>leutak</foreign> which have the same meaning.</note> is the wet rice field farmer, the strips of thorns are the foresters (<foreign>paṅalas</foreign>), the clutching rocks are the matchmakers (<foreign>paṅavin</foreign>), the cauldron is the <foreign>paməñəp</foreign>, the rice (? <foreign>naseya</foreign>) is the rice cooker, the wood-log is the pounder (<foreign>panutu</foreign>); the fire is the kitchen guardian (<foreign>tuṅgu dapur</foreign>), the one who cooks is the <foreign>harəp catra</foreign>; the water is the one who usually takes water for bathing; the cinder is the sweeper (<foreign>pañapu</foreign>); the livestock <supplied reason="subaudible">expert</supplied><note>My interpretation of <foreign>əsə</foreign> as ‘livestock’ is in the light of usu in OJ, where we find the derived forms <foreign>mosu</foreign> ‘to give birth’, <foreign>umusu</foreign> ‘to bear fruit’, <foreign>aṅusu-usu</foreign> ‘to lay eggs’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>usu</foreign>). In this case, <foreign>əsə</foreign> seems to allude to the animals’ reproduction. </note> is the chicken farmer, the boar farmer, the duck farmer; the one who <!-- finished 23 feb fn.118 google doc--> gives <supplied reason="subaudible">food</supplied> is the herdsman; the one who guards the lake, the one who guards the garden, anyone who guards domestic animals — <supplied reason="subaudible">all of them</supplied> are being enslaved by the god, <supplied reason="subaudible">they are</supplied> obstructed, used as hands and feet <supplied reason="subaudible">of the god</supplied>, do not have any power on their lives, on their destinies. That is called the misfortune from the three worlds.</p>
1995<p corresp="#smg_15.07">These are called the sorrow from the three worlds (<foreign>tri-bvana-loka</foreign>): the city is on fire, the harvest is failed, destroyed by disease, a long dry-season in an anomalous period,<note>On <foreign>laru kaṅkaṅ</foreign>, see OJED, s.v <foreign>lahrū kaṅkaṅ</foreign> ‘long dry season’. Cf. Udy 10.4 <foreign>lahrū kaṅkaṅ tan pakāla</foreign> “a long dry season is not at the [right] time”.</note> all kinds of fruit <supplied reason="subaudible">trees</supplied> do not bear fruit, all animals are scattered around <supplied reason="subaudible">dead</supplied>. That is called the sorrow of the three worlds. <foreign>ma, ṅya buku, u, sa, a</foreign>. Those are called the five misfortunes as said by the scholar, 5.</p></div>
.<div n="16" corresp="#smg_16"><p corresp="#smg_16.01">Again, as follows is what should be remembered by the servant of the dharma. There are what are called the five animals (<foreign>pañca-triyak</foreign>). These are the explanations: domestic animals (<foreign>pasu</foreign>), birds (<foreign>paksi</foreign>), snakes (<foreign>sarpa</foreign>), fishes (<foreign>mina</foreign>), <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> creeping animals (<foreign>pepelikan</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_16.02">Domestic animals (<foreign>pasu</foreign>) are all kinds of animals in the settlements; birds (<foreign>paksi</foreign>) are all kinds of animals on the side <supplied reason="subaudible">of the sea</supplied>;<note><foreign>di sisi</foreign>: Another way to interpret this is to take <foreign>di sisi</foreign> as an intransitive verb <foreign>disisi</foreign> ‘having sides i.e. having wings’. </note> snakes (<foreign>sarpa</foreign>) are all kinds of animals whose chest touch the ground; fishes (<foreign>mina</foreign>) are all kinds of animals in the water; creeping animals (<foreign>pepelikan</foreign>) are all kinds of animals having a shell, who crawl without being discovered. Their length of time from hell is 1100 years. Those are called the five animals.</p></div>
.<div n="17" corresp="#smg_17"><p corresp="#smg_17.01">The following should also be remembered. There are what are called the four roots. These are the explanations: <foreign>mantaja</foreign>,<note><foreign>mantaja</foreign>: cf. SKK 18.5–6 where we have <foreign>mataja</foreign> instead of <foreign>mantaja</foreign>. On the superfluous nasal, see chapter 3, §Morphology.</note> <foreign>urija</foreign>, <foreign>payuja</foreign>, <foreign>bagaja</foreign>. <foreign>Mantaja</foreign> means all kinds <supplied reason="subaudible">of things</supplied> born from the eye; <foreign>urija</foreign> means all kinds <supplied reason="subaudible">of things</supplied> born from the mouth;<note>In the corresponding SKK passage (18.5), we have <foreign>kurija</foreign>. It is not yet clear how the word <foreign>kuri</foreign> or <foreign>(v)uri</foreign> could express the meaning ‘mouth’ implied by the gloss <foreign>suṅut</foreign>. In OJ, <foreign>vuri</foreign> means ‘that which is left behind, trace’ (OJED, s.v. II). It reminds me of the expression <foreign>vāk-śeṣa</foreign> ‘trace of words’, which occurs several times in SHH, referring to the words of scholars of former times.</note> <foreign>payuja</foreign> means all kinds <supplied reason="subaudible">of things</supplied> born from the anus; <foreign>bagaja</foreign> means all kinds <supplied reason="subaudible">of things</supplied> born from sexual organs. The length of time <supplied reason="subaudible">before one who has sinned with those organs comes back</supplied> from hell is 100 years. Those are called the four roots, as declared by the scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="18" corresp="#smg_18"><p corresp="#smg_18.01">As follows are called<note>The clause <foreign>ini byaktana</foreign> seems out of place here. It is probably a corruption, so I skip this clause in the translation.</note> the four strengths (<foreign>catur-virya</foreign>). The meaning is: what is called joy is used to be hot tempered. The wealth is used to be rich. The hot temper is used to be overcome <supplied reason="subaudible">…</supplied>. The strength is used to give <supplied reason="subaudible">excessively</supplied> to those who are far, to those who are near, to the family and relatives. Those are called the four strengths. Those should be paid attention to, <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> should not be followed by the servant of <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p></div>
2000<div n="19" corresp="#smg_19"><p corresp="#smg_19.01">The following are called its ordinances (<foreign>kalpaənana</foreign>).<note><foreign>kalpaənana</foreign>: the word <foreign>kaləpasənana</foreign> seems to make no sense in this passage, since we have <foreign>catur-kalpa</foreign> as a subject of the topic, so I emend <foreign>kaləpasənana</foreign> to <foreign>kalpaənana</foreign>.</note> There are the holy immaculate four practices. This is the explanation: the people who are farmers, who are healthy (<foreign>purna</foreign>),<note>I interpret <foreign>purna</foreign> as ‘healthy’. See my comment on SKK 19.2.</note> who are very self-controlled (<foreign>sudanta</foreign>),<note>I interpret <foreign>sudanta</foreign> as ‘very self-controlled’, based on its meaning in OJ and Skt. (see OJED, s.v. <foreign>sudānta</foreign>).</note> who turned out well (<foreign>lastare</foreign>).<note>I consider <foreign>lastare</foreign> to be related to <foreign>lastari</foreign> in the MdS sense ‘vi. come to a good end, turn out well; (also as expr.) to pass away, die; bury good and proper, e.g. <foreign>geus lastari éta mayit</foreign>, the corpse has been recovered.’</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_19.02">The farmer (<foreign>tani</foreign>) means: <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> are advance in harvesting, tapping, putting the yoke, making quick ripening (? <foreign>ñavara</foreign>),<note>I presume that <foreign>ñavara</foreign> is related to MdS <foreign>hawara</foreign>, which Danadibrata (2006, s.v. <foreign>hawara</foreign>) defines as ‘a kind of paddy which is planted independent of the season’. Another meaning of <foreign>hawara</foreign> is ‘too early’.</note> taking care of the livestock, planting the crops. That is called the farmer. Those who are healthy (<foreign>purna</foreign>) means <supplied reason="subaudible">those who</supplied> do not have defects and diseases, <supplied reason="subaudible">and who</supplied> do not act like ordinary people.
