That is called <foreign>purna</foreign>. <foreign>Sudanta</foreign> means <supplied reason="subaudible">those</supplied> who can not be redeemed <supplied reason="subaudible">as a slave</supplied>, <supplied reason="subaudible">or</supplied> be strongly obstructed by debt. <foreign>Lastare</foreign> are people of the village who do not have illness, who do not have weakness.<note>My translation <foreign>hivaṅ</foreign> as ‘defect’ is based on its meaning in OJ (see OJED, s.v. <foreign>hivaṅ</foreign>). In MdS, we only find <foreign>hariwang</foreign> ‘apprehensive, anxious, concerned, worried’; presumably there once was a base form <foreign>hiwang</foreign>, but it is no longer in use.</note> That is called <foreign>lastare</foreign>. Those are called the four ordinances (<foreign>catur-kalpa</foreign>), as declared by the scholar. All that should be kept aside<note>The word <foreign>keñcakənən</foreign> literally means ‘to be put on the left side’. Contrasting to <foreign>katuhukənən</foreign> (lit. ‘to be put on the right side’), which denotes the meaning ‘to be followed’, I interpret <foreign>keñcakənən</foreign> as ‘to be put aside, to be abandoned’.</note> by the servant of <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p></div>
.<div n="20" corresp="#smg_20"><p corresp="#smg_20.01">This is what should be prioritized, <supplied reason="subaudible">namely</supplied> what are called the three bodies (<foreign>trikaya</foreign>), which are claimed as the source of beauty, the origin of splendor. There is what is called the pure circle of three bodily domains, as declared by the great scholar. <foreign>Tri</foreign> means three, <foreign>kaya</foreign> means what makes firm, <foreign>mandala</foreign> means the body, and what is called <foreign>suda</foreign> is already well known.<note>On the notion of <foreign>trikāya maṇḍala pariśuddha</foreign>, see chapter 11, §Dharma and Three Bodily Domains. This gloss reflects the Sundanese etymology, which is incorrect according to the meaning in Skt., since the author here understands <foreign>kaya</foreign> as ‘the means to make firm’ instead of ‘the body’. The phrase <foreign>aṅgəs kañahoan</foreign> seems to be an equivalent of the Skt. <foreign>ityuktam</foreign> in SiGu, meaning ‘so it is said by the people, well known’.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_20.02">Obey to the three bodily acts, as declared by the teacher, the three bodily acts of the world and of the people.<note>render <foreign>para</foreign> in the meaning of ‘others, another, other people, one’s fellow men, people at large’, based on its meaning in Skt. and OJ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>para</foreign> III)</note> What would those that are called the three bodily acts according to the teacher be? These are their metaphors: “Like the priceless gem and the desired gem, and also the real essence of gold.”<note><foreign>kady aṅganiṅ manik anarga, lavan manik sarvesta, lavan mas kanaka jatirupa</foreign>: cf. the same metaphor on gems and gold in SiGu 1.5.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_20.03">As follows is the threefold good. These are their kinds: pacifying thought, pacifying speech, pacifying intelect.<note>If we compare SiGu 8.2, we expect <foreign>karma pasanta</foreign> ‘pacified action’ instead of <foreign>budi pasanta</foreign> ‘pacifying intellect’.</note></p>
2005<p corresp="#smg_20.04">That which is called good actions, the explanations of good actions is: showing respect,<note>Hardjadibrata (s.v. <foreign>ngumun</foreign>) only records the active form of <foreign>umun</foreign>, i.e., <foreign>ngumun</foreign> ‘(in pantun stories, etc.) pay tribute to so., show respect (during the giving of <foreign>sembah</foreign>)’. Cf. SKK 4.7.</note> being faithful, honoring, being respectful, being afraid and fearful (i.e. being polite), agile, modest,<note>I take the reading msB <foreign>diteoh</foreign>, probably the intransitive form of the related word in MdS <foreign>téoh</foreign> ‘(dial.) low-lying area/place; <foreign>di téoh</foreign> below, on the ground; <foreign>(di) téoheun</foreign> under st. In this context it probably means ‘modest, humble’. The ms. A gives the reading <foreign>beteoh</foreign> which is also possible.</note> careful, thorough, diligent, persevering, charitable.<note>The word <foreign>paka pradana</foreign> (<foreign>prədana</foreign>) occurs several times in SKK. See my comment on this compound in SKK 1.4.</note> Those are called good actions.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_20.05">The good speeches are <supplied reason="subaudible">the words which are</supplied> friendly,<note>On the meaning of <foreign>sarseh</foreign>, cf. MdS <foreign>saréséh</foreign> ‘complaisant, friendly (towards guests), urbane’.</note> soft,<note>The word <foreign>saneh</foreign> (= MdS <foreign>sanéh</foreign>) is only recorded in Hardjadibrata’s dictionary ‘adj. (unc.) soft, friendly; <foreign>disanéh(-sanéh)</foreign> treated in a friendly manner’.</note> caring and loving, full of sympathy<note>The word <foreign>pesok</foreign> is not found in MdS, but it is attested in OS, e.g. in SA 980 <foreign>saur puah lakavati, pesok avakiṅ karuña, aiṅ ku atma visesa, nali təiṅ ti na moha, kasih di nu palaksana</foreign> “Puah Lakawati said: ‘I feel pity and compassion, for Atma Wisésa. He is too much attached to infatuated one, is loving one who is disobedient’.”. This context gives the impression that <foreign>pesok</foreign> should mean ‘to have pity’. Cf. SKK 14.3.</note> and compassion, persuasive,<note>My interpretation of <foreign>ṅaləgət</foreign> as ‘persuasive’ is based on a connection to the meaning of MdS <foreign>leugeut</foreign> ‘strong clinging latex of certain trees (<foreign>teureup</foreign>) and plants’ and MdJ <foreign>leget</foreign> ‘sticky’.</note> cooling the heart, praising,<note><foreign>mukpruk</foreign>: in MdS, <foreign>mukpruk(an)</foreign> means ‘overwhelm so., overburden with things (advice, goods, etc.); <foreign>mukpruk-mukpruk</foreign> and <foreign>makprak-mukpruk</foreign> s.m. (again and again), heap so. with gifts, give so. everything he wants to have; <foreign>pamukpruk</foreign> overwhelming gift-giving etc’. It seems that it had a broader meaning in OS, and here probably signifies ‘generous’, or in this case ‘praising’. In SKK 14.3 we have <foreign>mukpruk</foreign> instead of <foreign>mupruk</foreign>. For the /k/ ~ /ø/ variation, see chapter 3, §Phonology.</note> polite,<note>In MdS, <foreign>ngulas(an)</foreign> means ‘to polish st., coat st., spread st. (eg. with paint, whitewash, ointment, salve, oil, etc., also in conjunction with moistening of materials with water in traditional methods of weaving). It seems the secondary meaning of this word is ‘to be polite’.</note> propitiating; all kinds of perfect speeches. Those are called good speeches.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_20.06">The good mind means: <supplied reason="subaudible">like</supplied> “a clean side yard, a bright garden, a broad yard, a wide cultivated land”; it is put in action for giving food, money, clothes, girls <supplied reason="subaudible">in marriage</supplied>, and so on. Those are the four meritorious acts. Because of that <supplied reason="subaudible">one gets</supplied> a stable intellect, a clear mind, broad thinking,<note>The occurrence of <foreign>loganda</foreign> occurs more often in its combination with <foreign>ləga</foreign> ‘open, wide’, which seems to be a compound comparable to Mal. compounds with similar imitative reduplication: <foreign>porak-poranda</foreign>, <foreign>karut-marut</foreign>. See Sneddon 2010: 26. However, <foreign>loganda</foreign> in this passage seems to have a grammatical meaning.</note> a good intellect which is like a polished<note>On the word <foreign>inisuhan</foreign>, see OJED, s.v. <foreign>isuh, isuh-isuh</foreign> ‘washing’; cf. MdS <foreign>wasuh</foreign> ‘to wash’.</note> jewel, like the water on the <foreign>sulang</foreign><note><foreign>sulaṅ</foreign>: according to GNT <foreign>sulaṅ</foreign> refers to ‘kind of creeper, Epipremnum pinnatum’. Cf. the parallel expression in SA 327 <foreign>kadi cai di ron sulaṅ, bitan manik inisuhan</foreign> “like water in a sulang leaf, like a polished jewel”. Rigg (1862, s.v. <foreign>puchuk</foreign>) notes: “<foreign>Puchuk sulang</foreign>, said of seed paddy which will not come up, or which only throws up sickly white plants which soon die away. This is attributed to the seed being to old, or to its being stifled by lying piled in heaps, or that the air could not get at it”. Cf Mal. idiom <foreign>seperti air di daun keladi</foreign> ‘like water in a <foreign>keladi</foreign> leaf’. The idea is that the water (or the air) cannot penetrate the leaf, so the water is visibly clear like a jewel.</note> leaves, as a result of his good mind. That is called the pure circle of three bodily domains, as declared by the scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="21" corresp="#smg_21"><p corresp="#smg_21.01">These are called the four goodness. The verse<note>What the text calls a <foreign>siloka</foreign> is an example of vernacular verse in octosyllabic Old Javanese.</note> is as follows: “The gold, silver, luminous bezoar (<foreign>komala</foreign>), diamond”. The meaning is: the gold is a truthful, sincere, and correct word, the manifestation of the five sacred syllables. The silver means the perfect, meritorious, and good mind. The luminous bezoar means that his emotions are bright and shining, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> his thoughts are clear and broad. The diamond means to have a cheerful,<note>The word <foreign>caṅciṅ</foreign> is not recorded in MdS, but OJ has <foreign>caṅciṅ</foreign> ‘to hop’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>caṅciṅ</foreign>). Juxtaposed with <foreign>səri</foreign> ‘smile’, I translate it as ‘cheerful’. Cf. SKK 8.1.</note> smiley, agile, and joyful mind.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_21.02">This is the other meaning: what is called the gold is the pure gold, what is called the silver is the most desirable jewel, what is called luminous bezoar is the priceless jewel, what is called the diamond is the glowing gold.<note>On the word <foreign>santaṅva</foreign> considered as <foreign>santāpa</foreign> in OJ, see my comment on SiGu 1.5.</note> Those are called the four types of goodness.</p></div>
2010<div n="22" corresp="#smg_22"><p corresp="#smg_22.01">As for this one, it is the essence of goodness, called the ten holy virtues (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ dasa-sila</foreign>). <foreign>Dasa</foreign> means ten, <foreign>sila</foreign> means quality. These are the explanations: ear, eye, nose, tongue, mouth, skin, hand, sexual organs, anus, foot. Those are called the ten holy virtues.<note>On the explanation of <foreign>dasa-sila</foreign>, see chapter 11, §Daśa-śīla: Ten Virtues.</note></p></div>
.<div n="23" corresp="#smg_23"><p corresp="#smg_23.01">These are called<note><foreign>ini dasa-marga ṅaranna</foreign>: this first clause is the only clause in Old Sundanese, the whole sentences in this paragraph is in Old Javanese.</note> the ten paths (<foreign>dasa-marga</foreign>). <foreign>Śrotra</foreign> means ears. What is the sphere of ears? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should hear. <foreign>Cakṣuh</foreign> means eyes. What is the sphere of eyes? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should see. <foreign>Ghrāṇa</foreign> means the nose. What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should smell. <foreign>Jihvā</foreign> means the tongue. What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should taste. <foreign>Vāk</foreign> means the mouth. What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should speak about. <foreign>Tvak</foreign> means the skin. What is the sphere of the skin? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should touch.<note>The passive irrealis verb <foreign>prəsaakəna</foreign> is ultimately from Skt. <foreign>sparśa</foreign> ‘touch, sense of touch; the quality of tangibility’ (OJED s.v. <foreign>sparśa</foreign>). The hypothesized sound changes are as follows: <foreign>sparśa</foreign> &gt; <foreign>parsa</foreign> &gt; <foreign>prasa</foreign> &gt; <foreign>prəsa</foreign>. Cf. SC 275 <foreign>bayu sugan tan ana kaprəsa, sabda nu tan ana karəṅə, hdip tan ana kapiaṅən-aṅən</foreign> “The breath may not be grasped, no sound is heard, no idea comes to mind”. </note> <foreign>Pāṇi</foreign> means hands. What is the sphere of hands? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should grasp. <foreign>Pāyu</foreign> means anus. What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should release. <foreign>Pastha</foreign> means penis. What is the sphere of the penis? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should discharge. <foreign>Pāda</foreign> means feet. What is the sphere of the feet? What is bad should be avoided; goodness is what you should step on. Those are called the ten paths.</p></div>
.<div n="24" corresp="#smg_24"><p corresp="#smg_24.01">These are called the ten sense faculties. The sense of hearing resides in the ears. It exists in you;<note>My interpretation of the combination <foreign>sanika pananta</foreign> ‘it exists in you’ is tentative. We are probably dealing with the variant of OJ <foreign>sarika</foreign> ‘he, she, they; that, these (for respected persons; cf <foreign>rasika</foreign>)’ (OJED, s.v.). The word <foreign>pananta</foreign> is also uncertain, but it seems to be a variant of <foreign>pahananta</foreign>. However, the context indicates that all of the organs exist in the body. </note> it is the instrument of the holy soul. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The sense of sight resides in the eyes. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. It is the exit place of the mind. Its function is to perceive form and color. The sense of smell resides in the nose. It exists in you; <supplied reason="subaudible">it is</supplied> the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to smell. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The sense of taste resides in the tongue. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to taste the six flavors. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The sense of speech resides in the mouth. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to speak. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The sense of touch resides in the skin. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to touch. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The faculty of holding resides in the hands. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to seize. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The faculty of relief resides in the anus. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to fart. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. The sexual faculty resides in the penis. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to have sexual intercourse and to urinate. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. sThe faculty of walking resides in the feet. It exists in you; it is the instrument of the holy soul. Its function is to walk. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the exit place of the mind. Those are called the ten virtues.</p></div>
.<div n="25" corresp="#smg_25"><p corresp="#smg_25.01">This is called the ten personalisations. What is claimed by them is the hearing, the sight, the smelling, the speaking, the releasing, the urinating, the walking. There is the one who claims for himself, there is the one who hears, there is the holy floating jewel. It is called the ten personalisations.<note>The list in <foreign>dasa-paṅaku</foreign> only consists of eight faculties, so it seems the text is corrupt. If we follow the same logic as for <foreign>dasa-indriya</foreign>, we have lost <foreign>paṅrasa</foreign> for <foreign>jihvā</foreign>, and <foreign>paṅgaməl</foreign> for hand.</note></p></div>
.<div n="26" corresp="#smg_26"><p corresp="#smg_26.01">These are called the ten highest principles. These are the explanations: there are ears, there is hearing, there is the hearer, there is the highest principle. There are eyes, there is viewing, there is the viewer, there is the highest principle. There is nose, there is smelling, there is the smeller, there is the highest principle. There is tongue, there is taste, there is the taster, there is the highest principle. There is the mouth, there is the speech, there is the speaker, there is the highest principle. There is the skin, there is the touch, there is the toucher, there is the highest principle. There is the hand, there is the grasping, there is the grasper, there is the highest principle. There is the anus, there is the releasing, there is the releaser, there is the highest principle. There are the sexual organs, there is the urinating, there is the one who urinates, there is the highest principle. There are the feet, there is the walking, there is the walker, there is the highest principle. Those are called the ten highest principles.</p></div>
2015<div n="27" corresp="#smg_27"><p corresp="#smg_27.01">These are called the ten pacifiers. This is their explanation: donation (<foreign>dāna</foreign>), morality (<foreign>śīla</foreign>), forbearance (<foreign>kṣānti</foreign>), strength (<foreign>vīrya</foreign>), meditation (<foreign>dhyāna</foreign>), wisdom (<foreign>prajñā</foreign>), compassion (<foreign>karuṇā</foreign>), sympathy (<foreign>mudita</foreign>), friendship (<foreign>metrī</foreign>), endurance (<foreign>upekṣā</foreign>).<note><foreign>dasa-pasanta</foreign>: for the explanation of this concept, see chapter 11, §Borrowing Buddhist Doctrines.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_27.02">The meaning is: donation (<foreign>dāna</foreign>) means to give enjoyment to others. Morality (<foreign>śīla</foreign>) means to know etiquette (<foreign>tvah</foreign>). Strength (<foreign>vīrya</foreign>) means to strive to be continuously truthful, to strive to do goodness. Meditation (<foreign>dhyāna</foreign>) means to consider his own mind. Wisdom (<foreign>prajñā</foreign>) means to be quick to get rid of the bad things of oneself. Compassion (<foreign>karuṇā</foreign>) means his heart would be weak<note>In MdS, <foreign>béngkéng</foreign> means ‘have little resistance, fall easily sick; be sickly’, but it is clear that the author of SMG uses <foreign>beṅkeṅ</foreign> for translating OJ <foreign>grah</foreign> ‘weak, powerless (of the limbs)’ in SiGu (see OJED, s.v. <foreign>grah</foreign>).</note> while thinking for himself and does not want to make others sad. Sympathy (<foreign>mudita</foreign>) means not to forget the others’ skill. Friendship (<foreign>metrī</foreign>) means to know the good deed, to make the others feel at ease. Endurance (<foreign>upekṣā</foreign>) means not being bothered by the good and the bad. Those are called the ten pacifiers (<foreign>dasa-pasanta</foreign>).</p></div>
.<div n="28" corresp="#smg_28"><p corresp="#smg_28.01">This is what should be seriously done, what is called the ten grounds. These are the verses:</p>
.<p rend="stanza" corresp="#smg_28.02"><foreign>agəm rahayəm gunyam</foreign> | <foreign>tvah citane haləm</foreign> | <foreign>kurvanti kuśalam mahat</foreign><note>If we compare this passage to that of SiGu, SMG has extra two lines before <foreign>kurvanti kusalam mahat</foreign>.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_28.03">The excellent meritorious conduct should be carried out. The excellent meritorious conduct means: love (<foreign>asih</foreign>), devotion (<foreign>bhakti</foreign>), persevering effort (<foreign>prayatna</foreign>), respectability (<foreign>gorava</foreign>), honesty (<foreign>duga-duga</foreign>), calmness (<foreign>śānta</foreign>), compassion (<foreign>karuṇa</foreign>), sympathy (<foreign>anumoda</foreign>), consideration (<foreign>anumāna</foreign>), respectful mutual dependence (<foreign>ālambana atəaṅ</foreign>).<note>The word <foreign>atəaṅ</foreign> ‘respectful’ seems to be an OS equivalent of OJ <foreign>atvaṅ</foreign>, as it is found in SiGu. It is interesting that this word appears frequently in the twin form <foreign>atvaṅ atəaṅ</foreign> in OS texts.</note> Those are called ten grounds.</p></div>
2020<div n="29" corresp="#smg_29"><p corresp="#smg_29.01">These are called the ten superiorities (<foreign>dasa-visesa</foreign>). As follows is the meaning: the Holy<note>29.1 The qualities of <foreign>hyaṅ</foreign> in this context lead me to assume that this word is a personalization of Soul as the divine emanation.</note> hearing is not heard, because He is the one who hears, the Holy one who cannot be used as hearing. The Holy sight is not seen, because He is the one who sees, the Holy one who cannot be used as sight. The Holy smelling is not smelled, because He is the one who smells, the Holy one who cannot be used as smelling. The Holy taste is not tasted, because He is the one who tastes, the Holy one who cannot be used as taste. The Holy speech is not spoken, because He is the one who speaks, the Holy one who cannot be used as speech. The Holy touching is not touched, because He is the one who touches, the Holy one who cannot be used as touching. The Holy grasping is not grasped, because He is the one who grasps, the Holy one who cannot be used as grasping. The Holy release is not released, because He is the one who releases, The Holy one who cannot be used as releasing. The Holy urinating is not urinated, because He is the one who urinates, the Holy one who cannot be used as urinating. The Holy walking is not moving, because He is the one who moves, the Holy one who cannot be used as motion. Those are called the ten superiorities.</p></div>
.<div n="30" corresp="#smg_30"><p corresp="#smg_30.01">These are the ten supreme superiorities (<foreign>dasa-mahavisesa</foreign>). The Holy organ of hearing is materialized in your body, it is supreme because of the Supreme One. The Holy organ of sight is materialized in your body, it is supreme because of the Supreme One. The Holy organ of taste is materialized in your body, it is supreme because of the Supreme One. The Holy organ of speech is materialized in your body, it is supreme because of the Supreme One. The Holy organ of touch is materialized in your body; it is supreme because of the Supreme One, <supplied reason="subaudible">for the organ of touch itself</supplied> is not superior. The Holy organ of grasping is materialized in your body; it is supreme because of the Supreme One. The Holy organ of release is materialized in your body; it is supreme because the Supreme One, <supplied reason="subaudible">for the organ of release itself</supplied> is not superior. The Holy organ of urinating is materialized in your body; it is supreme because the Supreme One, <supplied reason="subaudible">for the organ of urinating itself</supplied> is not superior. Those are called the ten supreme superiorities.</p></div>
.<div n="31" corresp="#smg_31"><p corresp="#smg_31.01">These are called the ten non-superiorities (<foreign>dasa-tan-kavisesa</foreign>). The meaning is as follows: There is no hearing, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no sight, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning and vice in yourself. There is no smelling, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no taste, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no speech, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning and vice in yourself. There is no touch, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no grasping, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no release, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no urinating, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself. There is no walking, nothing is materialized in your body, there is no means for sinning in yourself, none of them.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_31.02">The meaning is: there is no one who hears, no one with form, no one who smells, no one who speaks, no one who touches, no one who grasps, no one who eats, no one no one who drinks, no one who tastes, there are no divine <supplied reason="subaudible">embodiments</supplied> for them. Those are called the ten non-superiorities.</p></div>
.<div n="32" corresp="#smg_32"><p corresp="#smg_32.01">Furthermore, my lesson for the servant of the dharma is as follows: There is what is called the four splendours; it is <supplied reason="subaudible">also</supplied> called the four principles. This is the meaning: <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> serve as the boat, <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> serve as the ship, <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> serve as the ark, <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> serve as the junk. What is compared to the boat is the pacified act, what is compared to the ship is the pacified speech, what is compared to the ark is the pacified thought, what is compared to the junk is the stable<note>On the word <foreign>atisti</foreign>, see Aditia Gunawan &amp; Griffiths (2021: 188). Here <foreign>atisti</foreign> is juxtaposed to <foreign>pasanta</foreign>, which seems to be the synonym, so it can be a twin form.</note> <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> pacified awareness. They are called the one of Siddha-nature (<foreign>sidajati</foreign>), the lord among yogins (<foreign>yogisvara</foreign>), the scholar (<foreign>pandita</foreign>), the men of religion (<foreign>viku</foreign>). Those are called the four splendours, those are called the four principles.</p></div>
2025<div n="33" corresp="#smg_33">
.<p corresp="#smg_33.01">These are called the four purities. The pure and transparent jewel is still, the pure jewel is clear, the pure jewel is white, those are the pure seat of thought (<foreign>cita</foreign>).<note>33.1 In Śaiva texts, this allusion to the unadulterated jewel refers to Śiva’s personified state. This sort of allusion is found, for example, in JS 19.5: <foreign>tiga avasthā ya saṅ puruṣa riṅ kaləpasan: hanān sakala, hanān kevala, hanān śuddha. katuturakəna sirān maṅkana: sakala ṅaranya makāvak triguṇa sira. kevala ṅaranya atiṅgal pamukti sira. malinatva ṅaranya papasahnira mvaṅ triguṇa, manovijñānāvak-nira, śuddha ṅaranya patiniṅ manovijñāna sakeṅ sira. māri mamikalpa, śūnyākāra, kaivalya, tan hana gələh-gələh nirān pamukti. sira sinaṅguh nirmala-śiva</foreign> “There are three stages for man to reach Release: there is the manifest, there is the isolated, and there is the pure. These should be taught as follows: Manifest means embodied in the three constituents. Isolated means to have given up enjoyment. Dirt means its connection with the three constituents. Perception-through-the-mind (<foreign>manovijñāna</foreign>) is its body. Pure means that the end of Perception through the mind is caused by it. It ceases to have activities, it is Void, it is Isolation, there is no stain in its Release. That is called the Spotless Śiva”.</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_33.02">The following is also to be taken into account carefully. There is what is called the origin of goodness. It is that which is extraordinary and very secret. It is the holy virtue.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_33.03">This is called the release, the holy purity. It is called the four final liberations (<foreign>catur-mokta</foreign>): release, disappearance, vanishing, dissolution. That is called the four final liberations. That should be kept in secret by the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p></div>
.<div n="34" corresp="#smg_34"><p corresp="#smg_34.01">This is the six and two.<note>The meaning of <foreign>sad ro</foreign> ‘six and two’ is very obscure. If it refers to the number of explanations of the syllable <foreign>ndah saṅ hyaṅ hayu</foreign>, then we have five items, not two or six. In 34.2 we have the explanation of <foreign>ro</foreign> which means ‘the two’.</note> The meaning <supplied reason="subaudible">is in the words</supplied> <foreign>ndah saṅ hyaṅ hayu</foreign>. The meaning is: <foreign>nən</foreign> is like the king who thinks, who reflects carefully when he is on the sacred throne, emerges from the condition of stability. That is called <foreign>nən</foreign>. The <foreign>dah</foreign> is the willingness to present the possessions to the king, elders, hermits, ritualists, and sailors. The <foreign>saṅ</foreign> means, it is said, single; there is certainly no second, and also no third. What is called <foreign>hyaṅ</foreign> is the relic of the past.<note>This statement reinforces the idea that <foreign>hyaṅ</foreign> refers to the divine ancestors.</note> What is called <foreign>hayu</foreign> means lightweight, it is said, the body is like a flower-bud and a kapok fiber.<note>Allusions to the lightweight as kapok and flower-bud are mentioned in several texts. This allusion usually refers to one of eight supernatural powers, <foreign>laghiman</foreign> ‘absence of weight’, possessed by Śiva or the lords of yogins. Cf. DhPat 330: <foreign>laghiman ṅaranya, abyə̄̄t avaknira tambhayan vəkasan mahaṅan kadi kapuk</foreign> “Weightlessness means: first his body is heavy, then it is light like kapok”; BS 62.3 <foreign>olih nəm yuga, aḍaṅan avake kadi pusuh</foreign> ‘the result of the yoga number six: his body is light as cotton’.</note> Those are the truths. That is the one who <foreign>aro ṅe</foreign>?<note>The phrase <foreign>saṅ aro ṅe</foreign> is unintelligible; it should probably be emended to <foreign>sad ro, ṅa</foreign>.</note></p>
2030<p corresp="#smg_34.02">This is the meaning of two: that is one man <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> one woman, it is called two. Three means the king, the elder, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> the hermit, 3. Five means Brahma, Wisnu, Iswara, Mahadéwa, Siwa Sangkara; Kusika, Garga, Méstri, Purusya, Patañjala; Indra, Yama, Baruna, Kuwéra, Bésawarna. That is called the five gods. Seven means: the seven underworlds, the seven middle worlds, the seven upperworlds, the seven voids, the Absolute. That is called the account of the creation (<foreign>kalpa-carita</foreign>).<note>On the term <foreign>kalpa-carita</foreign>, cf. SKK 11.30; SHH 1.1–12. According to SHH, <foreign>kalpa-carita</foreign> is the account of cosmology. See chapter 11, §Cosmology.</note></p></div>
.<div n="35" corresp="#smg_35"><p corresp="#smg_35.01">These are called the three in number: three categories (3),<note>This seems to refer to <foreign>pakṣa tiga</foreign> ‘categories of triad’, one of the topics in SHH 2.1–2: <foreign>ndatan kami juga maṅucap tiga, paḍa sira mpu kabeh maṅucap tiga, ndya lvir-nikaṅ tiga vinuvusnira, nyaṅ brahmā, viṣṇu, īśvāra, tiga atika liṅ saṅ vaneh, nihan taṅ buddhi, guṇa, pradhāna, triyantahkaraṇa ṅaranya, tiga atika liṅ saṅ vaneh, nihan taṅ prabhu, rāma, r̥ṣi, sinaṅgah <foreign>tri-tantu</foreign></foreign> “It is not only I who speak of three; all the reverends speak of three. What are the threes they speak of? They are Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Īśvara. The three, as others say, are as follows: intellect, quality, and primary matter, called the three internal faculties. The three, as others say, are as follows: the (local) ruler, the village elder, the hermit, called the three threads”.</note> three inconclusive <supplied reason="subaudible">propositions</supplied> (3), the means of knowledge (4), the artificial knowledge<note><foreign>ajñāna ginavay-gavay</foreign> ‘artificial knowledge’, as opposed to true knowledge (<foreign>ajñāna jāti</foreign>) is one of the issues discussed in SHH 3.</note> (4). These are the breath, the speech, and the people’s mind, which surround (<foreign>narivrəta</foreign>)<note>The word <foreign>narivrəta</foreign> probably corresponds to OJ <foreign>umarivṛtta</foreign> ‘to surround, accompany, assist, attend’, from Skt. <foreign>parivr̥ta</foreign> ‘train, suite, assistant, companion’ (OJED, s.v. <foreign>parivr̥ta</foreign>). On the idea that the three elements covers all beings, see chapter 11, §Tiga Sādhana.</note> the world, which sink (? <foreign>ñəluman</foreign>)<note>I interpret <foreign>ñəluman</foreign> as a variant of the expected word <foreign>ñiləman</foreign> (from <foreign>siləm</foreign>) ‘to sink, to drown’, and render it as ‘to sink, to absorb’. </note> into the trees, into the rock, into the earth, into the water, into every kind of plant, into the animals (3).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.02">These are the three <supplied reason="subaudible">existing</supplied> in the scholar. It is called the <foreign>tiga sadana</foreign>: <foreign>tiga</foreign> means three, <foreign>sadana</foreign> means element.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.03">These are called the three truths. This is <supplied reason="subaudible">the syllables</supplied> <foreign>a</foreign>, <foreign>ña</foreign>, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> <foreign>na</foreign>. That is called the three true words.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.04"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil</supplied>: “Where can the three be found in the scholar? Show your favour to your son <supplied reason="subaudible">by revealing</supplied> about the location where the <foreign>a</foreign>, the <foreign>ña</foreign>, and the <foreign>na</foreign> can be found!”<note>From this paragraph to 35.10 we encounter the exposition shifts into dialog.</note></p>
2035<p corresp="#smg_35.05"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> “So be it. As follows. First I will explain the equality and the difference, your means to know the truth of the three. What is the meaning of the <foreign>vari</foreign>, <foreign>srigadiṅ</foreign>, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> <foreign>asoka</foreign> flowers? You should explain! Are they identical?”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.06"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> “So be it. They are different, my lord. The <foreign>vari</foreign> flower is still the <foreign>vari</foreign> flower. The <foreign>srigadiṅ</foreign> is still the <foreign>srigadiṅ</foreign>, the <foreign>asoka</foreign> is still the <foreign>asoka</foreign>, my lord. Please tell <supplied reason="subaudible">me</supplied> your words.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.07"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> “The three are like that, the means to evaluate the equality and the difference in a sincere, truthful, rightful, and clearly perceived manner.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.08"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> “First of all, here is the instrument to evaluate the equality and the difference of the <foreign>a</foreign>. What is entering and exiting by means of the nose and of your mouth, <foreign>upamāna praveśanam</foreign>, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> its use in your body?”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.09"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> “The wind as breath, my lord. That is what is called <foreign>a</foreign>, according to the scholars.”</p>
2040<p corresp="#smg_35.10"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> “As follows is what could also be asked regarding that <supplied reason="subaudible">issue</supplied>. What is the name that is heard, as the thunder and thunderous noise of all beings? What are the<supplied reason="subaudible">ir</supplied> names, according to you?”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.11"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> “The sound, my lord! That is called the <foreign>ña</foreign>, according to the scholars.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.12"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> “As follows is what could also be asked, there is nobody who knows about it. What is the meaning of that which is caused by you to reach the limit of the world: north, south, west, east, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> in a wink it crosses the ocean, disappears and comes back again in an instant? What is your opinion, my son?”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.13"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> “The mind, my lord! That is called the na, according to the scholars.</p> <p corresp="#smg_35.14">That is the reason why they are called breath, speech, and mind, which are spread through the world. Those are called the three instruments. They are the means to reach the world; <supplied reason="subaudible">they</supplied> are used as a support for all beings.”</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_35.15">These are the activities in the body. <foreign>Bayu</foreign> serves as the vital principle, entering and exiting your nose; it serves as your breath. It is considered right, correct, and clearly perceived. It is called the truth in the body. <foreign>Sabda</foreign> means the speech. It is used to define the bad and the good, to name vowels and consonants. It serves as your speech. <foreign>Hədap</foreign> means the mind, your thoughts directed towards the near and the far.</p>
2045<p corresp="#smg_35.16">The <foreign>a</foreign> is the breath, the <foreign>ña</foreign> is the speech, the <foreign>na</foreign> is the mind. <supplied reason="subaudible">They are</supplied> the content of the three knowledges (<foreign>tiga ajñana</foreign>), which are the first argument of the scholars. They should be taught <supplied reason="subaudible">as follows:</supplied> <foreign>tiga</foreign> means three, <foreign>ajñana</foreign> means the place to be reached (<foreign>kasampəran</foreign>). It is the Great Supreme (4).</p></div>
.<div n="36" corresp="#smg_36"><p corresp="#smg_36.01">Furthermore, this is called the innate knowledge. It can not be given to the pupil, it can not be faked. The knowledge and the real are the origin of the Supreme One.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_36.02">This is the excellent <supplied reason="subaudible">principle</supplied>, the origin of joy and sorrow, what is pleasant <supplied reason="subaudible">and unpleasant?</supplied>. That is the reason why <supplied reason="subaudible">it is</supplied> the origin of power and strength, the origin of being respected, the origin of being endowed, the origin of being venerated in the case of the scholar. As for the existence of the breath, speech, and mind in your body: if the breath, speech, and mind vanish in your body, <supplied reason="subaudible">it means that one</supplied> ceases to be venerated, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> ceases to be worshiped.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_36.03">The mind is used as the mind by wisdom. The mind is manifold. It is the truth and correct. It is truly perceivable in the body. It is called the three truths. <foreign>Tri</foreign> means three, <foreign>təpət</foreign> means superior.</p></div>
.<div n="37" corresp="#smg_37"><p corresp="#smg_37.01"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> This is their union. The “straight” is the thought, far and near. Its entire life and its targets are not hindered by the difficulties. It reaches the edges of the world-egg, <supplied reason="subaudible">including</supplied> heaven and the underworlds, unseen during day and night. It is called “to achieve the ultimate” <supplied reason="explanation"><foreign>boṅboṅ botos</foreign></supplied><note><foreign>boṅboṅ botos</foreign> seems to be an expression. We find such expression in MdS <foreign>tutas titis bongbong bontos</foreign> ‘have completed learning’.</note> and “to completely dissolve” <supplied reason="explanation"><foreign>buṅbaṅ ləpas</foreign></supplied>.<note><foreign>buṅbaṅ ləpas</foreign> also seems to be a similar expression to <foreign>boṅboṅ botos</foreign>. In MdS, <foreign>buṅbaṅ</foreign> signifies ‘cut down clean, stripped of (unwanted) vegetation’, and <foreign>ləpa</foreign>s means ‘release’. So it probably means ‘to clearly dissolve’. </note> Those whose desires, all <supplied reason="subaudible">of them</supplied>, are true and <foreign>rasti</foreign> <supplied reason="explanation">?</supplied> are leaving without being noticed. What is the meaning of such <supplied reason="subaudible">teaching</supplied>?</p>
2050<p corresp="#smg_37.02"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> <supplied reason="subaudible">This is</supplied> the thought indeed, my lord.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_37.03"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> That is the holy knowledge, according to the scholar. It is the union of the three truths. When the beauty <supplied reason="subaudible">of knowledge</supplied> is thrown away, it is called the carcass. That is the reason why supreme knowledge is the origin of ultimate excellence.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_37.04">What is the form of what is called the truly priceless? This is your metaphor: like the court filled with the gold, jewel, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> priceless clothes of the worthy king. All of that is truly priceless. Thus <supplied reason="subaudible">far</supplied> about the existence of the holy breath, speech and mind. Thus is the supreme knowledge in your body.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_37.05">Indeed, the holy knowledge regarding the living as a householder (<foreign>momah</foreign>), of breathing, of speaking, of thinking is no other than the holy supreme knowledge. Its meaning is to be kept as a secret by the pupil of the scholar.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_37.06"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> So be it. This is fortunate.</p></div>
2055<div n="38" corresp="#smg_38"><p corresp="#smg_38.01"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> This is my word, the endless wisdom. Is there any breath, speech, and mind in you, my child?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.02"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> Yes, they exist, my lord.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.03"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> Is it seen by you?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.04"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> No, my lord. It is proper to regard it as existing. Anything that is felt and touched, it exists in the world and in the body, my lord.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.05"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> Such <supplied reason="subaudible">answer</supplied> is true. Does the speech exist?</p>
2060<p corresp="#smg_38.06"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> It exists, my lord.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.07"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> Such <supplied reason="subaudible">answer</supplied> is true. Is the speech seen by you?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.08"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> No, it is not seen, my lord. It is proper to regard it as existing. All that is heard, it exists in the world and in the body, my lord.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.09"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> Does the mind exist in you?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.10"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> It exists, my lord.</p>
2065<p corresp="#smg_38.11"><supplied reason="subaudible">Teacher:</supplied> Is it seen by you?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.12"><supplied reason="subaudible">Pupil:</supplied> No, it is not seen, my lord. It is proper to regard it as existing. All that is thought, far and near, exists in the world and in the body.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.13"><supplied reason="subaudible">Master:</supplied> You are right to know in this way. That is the reason why what is called the Holy Invisible <supplied reason="subaudible">essence</supplied> is clearly perceptible; it exists perpetually in the body and <supplied reason="subaudible">in</supplied> the world, there is nothing else.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_38.14">This is the activity of the breath, the speech, and the mind: the appellation of the breath, speech, and mind (3), the demonstration of the breath (6). This is the five tasks ordered by the king (5), the five organs (5), the teaching about the way to vanish (3), the highest truth (<foreign>paramarta</foreign>) (4), the ultimate isolation (4), the eight supernatural powers (8), the section of knowledge (3), <foreign>kisiñan</foreign>;(?) (8), unperceived by faculties (<foreign>anendriya</foreign>)<note>My interpretation of <foreign>anendriya</foreign> is based on its occurrence in SHH 40.1: <foreign>anendriya ṅaranya tar katon taṅ panon</foreign> “anendriya means it can not seen by the eyes”.</note> (3), the gross and subtle elements (4). These are the numbers of the section of knowledge; the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign> should pay attention to them.</p></div>
.<div n="39" corresp="#smg_39"><p corresp="#smg_39.01">This is called the addition (2), the state of the <foreign>viku</foreign>s (4), the naming <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> the personalisation <supplied reason="subaudible">of</supplied> the reverend teacher. This is what should be made an object of attention by the one who searches for the truth. <supplied reason="subaudible">It is</supplied> the holy knowledge: the reason that <supplied reason="subaudible">it is</supplied> the possession of one who possesses, the reason that it is not used as a possession, like the enjoyment <supplied reason="subaudible">of consumption</supplied> (<foreign>boga</foreign>), enjoyment <supplied reason="subaudible">of living properties</supplied> (<foreign>pariboga</foreign>), enjoyments of appearance (<foreign>rupaboga</foreign>).<note>The distinction between <foreign>boga</foreign>, <foreign>pariboga</foreign>, and <foreign>rupaboga</foreign> in this text is different from the one attested in Old Javanese texts. For example, in the Koravāśrama, we find <foreign>bhoga</foreign> and <foreign>paribhoga</foreign>, where <foreign>bhoga</foreign> is the pleasure of eating and drinking while <foreign>paribhoga</foreign> is the pleasure of dress and adornment (<foreign>sandaṅ aṅgo</foreign>). The combination of <foreign>rūpabhoga</foreign> never occurs in Old Javanese sources, where we find <foreign>upabhoga</foreign> instead. See Vṛt 28.1: <foreign>bhoga aranya salwir iṅ kapaṅan kenum, upabhoga aranya salvir iṅ sinaṇḍaṅ, paribhoga aranya ikaṅ marabi mahulun</foreign>. Thus, <foreign>rupaboga</foreign> may be a later development through reanalyzing.</note> What is that which is called <foreign>boga</foreign>, <foreign>pariboga</foreign>, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> <foreign>rupaboga</foreign>?</p>
2070<p corresp="#smg_39.02">As follows: what is called <foreign>boga</foreign> is food and drink; <foreign>pariboga</foreign> is the slave, servant, buffalo, cow, any kind of livestock; <foreign>rupaboga</foreign> is gold, jewel, fine lower cloths for a worthy king, that is, the ornaments of a divine king. The possession is the supreme knowledge, to be used as the embellishment <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> as the ornament of the substance of the individual (<foreign>vastu si vvaṅ</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_39.03">In addition, O child of the scholar, what will be thought should be absorbed, about what is called the substance of the individual.<note>My emendation <foreign>vastu siṅ voṅ</foreign> to <foreign>vastu si voṅ</foreign> ‘the substance of the individual’ is in the light of SKK 18, where we have <foreign>vastu si voṅ</foreign> as the highest type of being, after plant beings (<foreign>janma tumuvuh</foreign>), animal beings (<foreign>janma triyak</foreign>), human beings (<foreign>janma voṅ</foreign>), and individual beings (<foreign>janma si voṅ</foreign>).</note></p>
.<p corresp="#smg_39.04">Let it be so! <supplied reason="subaudible">I</supplied> teach you as follows: what is called a worthy person is the one of true being (<foreign>saṅ sat-hana</foreign>), <supplied reason="subaudible">which is</supplied> not created. It is the source. It is called the root of the origin and the end. It is called pure nature. It is called the source of the mother and father. It is regarded as the secret. It is called the paramount <foreign>dharma</foreign>, who carries out all the actions in the world. He creates without joining <supplied reason="subaudible">all the other beings in</supplied> being created. That is why what is called “Someone” (<foreign>si anu</foreign>) does not come from the treatises, does not come from the teacher, <supplied reason="subaudible">but</supplied> it is from oneself (<foreign>na śāstrataḥ na gurutaḥ svataḥ</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_39.05">The meaning is: <foreign>na śāstrataḥ</foreign> <supplied reason="subaudible">means</supplied> cannot be found by the means of scriptures and wisdom; <foreign>na gurutaḥ</foreign> is <foreign>kaimariṅun</foreign> (?). What is sought <supplied reason="subaudible">by him</supplied> is penetrated and filled. It cannot be used as a means, it cannot be instructed, by (<foreign>ri</foreign>) the teacher. It is only from oneself. It exists without being made into existence: no wife, no son, no relatives, no mother, no father: <supplied reason="subaudible">it is</supplied> from oneself. The meaning is: <foreign>na bhārya</foreign> is not having a wife, na <foreign>putraḥ</foreign> is not having child and grandchild, <foreign>na mātā</foreign>, <foreign>na pitam svataḥ</foreign> is not having a father, not having a mother.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_39.06"><foreign>Avismṛtidṛṣṭi</foreign> (the sight of one who is not forgetful). He sees without being seen, knows without being known, embodies without being embodied, blows the vital air <supplied reason="subaudible">into other beings</supplied> without being blown the vital air into <supplied reason="subaudible">by any other beings</supplied>, speaks without being spoken, thinks without being thought. He appears just at the same time with his body, his breath, his speech, and his mind, in the embryo-abode in the past. When he appears in the external <supplied reason="subaudible">world</supplied>, he is called “Someone”.</p>
2075<p corresp="#smg_39.07">That is the reason why the Someone else is called the one having difficulty, namely, its ignorance about the world and the universe is extraordinary, is not knowing the father and the mother of the whole world, and the child of the world. Who is the one who is knowledgeable? It is only the scholar, no one else.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_39.08">O, child of the learned master, “Someone” will emerge from what are called parents.</p></div>
.<div n="40" corresp="#smg_40"><p corresp="#smg_40.01">Indeed, the following is my love for you (5). These are the <foreign>vari</foreign>s flowers. The meaning is as follows: <foreign>vari</foreign>s flowers means cotton, the color means a thread, the cognition (<foreign>vri</foreign>)<note>The word <foreign>vri</foreign> in OJ is equivalent with <foreign>vruh i</foreign> (OJED, s.v. <foreign>vri</foreign> II). In our context, the fabric (<foreign>boeh</foreign>) is connected with the individualized divine emanation (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ pramana</foreign>), then my interpretation of <foreign>vri</foreign> as ‘cognition’ seems to make sense. </note> means fabric.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_40.02">The meaning is: what is called <foreign>vari</foreign>s flowers is the body, what is called the thread is the mind, what is called fabric is the individualized divine emanation (<foreign>saṅ hyaṅ pramana</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_40.03">The meaning is: he uses his mind as the sight, he uses his two eyes as the gate, he uses his breath as the vital principle, he uses his speech as the means of realizing, he uses his body as the abode, he uses the world as the gate.</p>
2080<p corresp="#smg_40.04">The ‘red’ is a color, the meaning is that <supplied reason="subaudible">he</supplied> knows what he sees. The gate to see the varis flowers is the two eyeballs. The instrument to see the varis flowers is the mind. It means that he knows his sight. Who is the one who sees the <foreign>varis</foreign> flowers?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_40.05">It is you, son.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_40.06">The skill (3), the truth (1), its <foreign>panatab</foreign> (?) (3), the liberated soul (9), inconceivable, <foreign>icaluṅ</foreign> (?), <foreign>i</foreign> (?), to carry over the shoulder, <foreign>ba</foreign> (?), the big trees (<foreign>kayu magəṅ</foreign>).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_40.07">This is the five gross elements (5), the five forms <supplied reason="subaudible">of suffering</supplied>, (5), the five paths (5). All of that should be made the object of the attention of the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</p></div>
.<div n="41" corresp="#smg_41"><p corresp="#smg_41.01">As follows is the esoteric teaching, the beginning of the scholar telling about the <supplied reason="subaudible">five</supplied> sections. The esoteric teaching (<foreign>sandi</foreign>) means the consciousness. It serves as the direction of the world and all beings. That is the reason why <supplied reason="subaudible">every being in</supplied> the whole world does not <supplied reason="subaudible">come to existence</supplied> with a wrong body and with a wrong condition. All the beings are following, in the right direction, their father and their mother, and their origin and particular nature: humans give birth to humans, animals give birth to animals.</p>
2085<p corresp="#smg_41.02">What is called penance (<foreign>tapa</foreign>) is as follows. What is the essential meaning of it? The purity (<foreign>si lilaṅ</foreign>). What is the reason it is called purity? Its explanation is as follows: it is aware to have the world and the body as properties.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_41.03">Likewise, the posture (<foreign>luṅguh</foreign>), what is the essential meaning of it? The firmness. It is true indeed that The Witness is firm in his knowledge of the manifest and unmanifest world. What is the firmness of The Witness in the manifest world? He does not follow along <supplied reason="subaudible">others</supplied> in prioritizing sacred formulas, mantras, the mantra <foreign>huṅ</foreign>, a lotus-like hand (<foreign>padmakara</foreign>),<note>I emend <foreign>padkara</foreign> to <foreign>padmakara</foreign> is in the light of a passage in BhK <foreign>śloka</foreign> 12 and its OJ exegesis: <foreign>saṅ hyaṅ śivabhasma kavruhana saṅ sādhaka | irikaṅ karatāla vedi | ikaṅ aṅguli ya samīt | tulisniṅ karatāla ya padmamaṇḍala</foreign> “The holy ashes of Śiva should be known by the practitioner: the altar is in the palm; the fingers are the firewood; the lines of the palm are the lotus-maṇḍala”.</note> and also performing worship and healing spells (<foreign>jampa-jampya</foreign>). You do not follow those in prioritizing the way of penance, observances, yoga, and concentration. He is not seduced<note>The passive word <foreign>kavacica</foreign> it is not attested in OJ, but occurs in OS ‘enthralled, seduced, overwhelmed, obstructed’. Noorduyn &amp; Teeuw are in doubt because <foreign>kavacica</foreign> and <foreign>kavañcica</foreign> occur in SA. The etymology of this word is unclear.</note> by any kind of supernatural powers (<foreign>guna</foreign>). Those are the firmness of The Witness in the manifest world. What is the firmness of The Witness in the unmanifest world? He should not be involved in demonic <supplied reason="subaudible">activities</supplied>.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_41.04">Likewise, the direct perception (<foreign>pratyaksa</foreign>), what is its essential meaning? The impossibility. What is the meaning of impossibility? This is its nature: Does The One know about the impossibility of the whole world being used as its world? No. Does The Witness know that the body is used as its body? No. Does the The Holy Dharma know that the smell is used as its smell? No. Does the Holy Virtue know that the colour is used as its colour? No. Does The Divine Emanation know that the breath, speech, and mind are used as its life? No. Does The Supreme One know that the speech is used as its means to define? No. Does The Holy Secret know that the mind is used as an instrument of thought? That is called the impossibility.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_41.05">Where does the impossibility and the application of the impossibility come from? As follows: the consciousness in the mind. There is the most desired jewel, beautiful and fulfilling. The Witness is the most desired jewel and the great unconceivable one. It <supplied reason="subaudible"><foreign>manik sarvesta</foreign></supplied> is treated with much fondness by the holy dharma.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_41.06">What is that which is called the most desired jewel, beautiful and fulfilling? It is the mind. What is the beautiful jewel belonging to ‘the creator (<foreign>anuṅ vidi</foreign>)’? It is consciousness. What is the beautiful jewel and the greatly inconceivable one? It is The Witness. Those are called the three secret words. The secret of the scholar is not found by the servant of the dharma.</p></div>
2090<div n="42" corresp="#smg_42"><p corresp="#smg_42.01">What are called the three secrets, that is the breath, the speech, and the mind? Those which are called the three secrets are not the three means. The meaning is: what is called the three secrets according to the great teacher?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.02">Indeed, as follows is its form: that is the mind, the consciousness, the witness. Those are called the origin of existence. What is the explanation of the origin of existence, my lord? The illustration about that is as follows: like the lamp, the flame, and the light.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.03">Are the flame and the light identical, my lord?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.04">No, they are not like that. The flame, the light, and the fire are different. The flame and the light are coming out from the fire. Their outcome dies with the fire, going back to their origin; their original condition dies.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.05">What is its explanation? Prepare the torch already! Its nature is to suddenly flame firmly, and at the same time, is to be extinguished. The appearance of the flame is <supplied reason="subaudible">also</supplied> the appearance of the light. In a similar way they are extinguished. The swallow of the flame and the light, they are swallowed and vanished simultaneously. The mind and the consciousness, as well as the witness are likewise.</p>
2095<p corresp="#smg_42.06">What is considered the fire? The individualized divine emanation. What is the flame? The mind. What is the heat and the light? The esoteric <supplied reason="subaudible">consciousness</supplied>. The meaning is: the mind, the consciousness, <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> the witness. Those are called the origin of existence (3).</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.07">This is the means of individualization, like the painter, the action <supplied reason="subaudible">of painting</supplied>, and the brush; like the bronze and the wax, along with the silver. The meaning is: the mind, the consciousness, the witness. Those are called the means of individualization of existence.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.08">This is the meaning that the fire is different. What is the explanation? Prepare the lamp, that is, its wick is set ablaze. <supplied reason="subaudible">The fire</supplied> that stands and flames, quickly shines. Its measure stands in the same direction (satuduhan). That is called the flame. What is spreading out <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> filling the house, it is called the light. What is shining as small as a fire-fly, and the red on the top of the wick, that is called the fire. This is the proof that the fire is different from the flame and the light. Where to the destination of the flame and the light? Does it go to void and non-existence? No, it is not like that.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.09">What is the meaning of all of this, <supplied reason="subaudible">about the fire</supplied> going to the void and non-existence? No, it is not like that. What is the meaning of all this, <supplied reason="subaudible">namely</supplied> the flame, along with the light and its fire, going to the void and non-existence, according to another <foreign>viku</foreign>? No, it is not according to the scholar. You should not <supplied reason="subaudible">say</supplied> like that.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.10">Where would be the destination of the torch and its light? They go to the state that exists. The meaning is: like the egg, like the seed of mango, like the rice-straw, like planting in the rice field, like the flowers and the yarn, sa, a.</p>
2100<p corresp="#smg_42.11">That is called the work of the Lord. This is the power of the Great One. This is the power of the Supreme One. Me means I, the one who truly exists, which is not created, the holy one who exists by itself, who creates which does not follow <supplied reason="subaudible">others</supplied> in being created. Because I am the life-giving power which is not the embodiment of the living power (<foreign>kapramanaan</foreign>). I am the Supreme which is not the embodiment of the Supreme. That is called the three supreme secrets.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.12">This is its means of tatab (? <foreign>panatabna</foreign>). The world has ceased to support, the body has ceased to serve as the abiding place, the breath has ceased to be the vital principle, the speech has ceased to be used as a means to put into effect, the mind has ceased to be produced, the consciousness has ceased to be the instrument of action, the witness has ceased to act upon. This is the explanation according to the noble master.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.13">This is the means of their union (<foreign>pamupul</foreign>). The mind has ceased to be created, the consciousness has ceased to be used as an instrument to create, the Witness has ceased to create. That is called the means of the union.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.14">This is the means of coloring (? <foreign>pamulas</foreign>). The mind acknowledges (? <foreign>maṅku</foreign>) that it has ceased to be made upon by that (<foreign>tutur</foreign>); the consciousness acknowledges (? <foreign>maṅku</foreign>) has ceased to create by way of that (<foreign>hədap</foreign>); the Witness, consequently, has ceased to act by way of people. It is called its means of coloring.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_42.15">This is called its fixation. It is not seen. What is made and the instrument of action, let alone the one who acts are visualized. For the mind is subtle. It has ceased to be created. The consciousness is invisible. It has ceased to be created. The Witness is inconceivable. Those are called the process of fixation, of what is called the three secrets.</p></div>
2105<div n="43" corresp="#smg_43"><p corresp="#smg_43.01">Likewise is the release. What serves as the secret by him to act? That is called the process of fixation. The creation (<foreign>krataka</foreign>) and the sharing task (<foreign>si dum</foreign>). The meaning is: The Witness will know the means to the act, <supplied reason="subaudible">He</supplied> will know to arrange his acts in the material <supplied reason="subaudible">and</supplied> immaterial world.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_43.02">What is your analogy? Like the goldsmith. The one who gave the order comes. <supplied reason="subaudible">He says:</supplied> “Please make for me a bracelet and a ring”. The smith says “I already abandoned my work. It was already given by me to the assistant. The occupation is abandoned by me. Already a long time that the skill was left by me.” The one who gave the order then left, he was looking for another smith.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_43.03">Likewise also the individualized divine emanation. “The painter” has ceased to create. The Witness has ceased to cause the consciousness. All of them have ceased to be constitutive elements <supplied reason="subaudible">of the human being</supplied>. That is why that is called being apportioned <supplied reason="subaudible">according to their original prerogatives</supplied>: have limit without being limited with regard to their manifest and unmanifest activities. The meaning is: that is called the release according to the scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="44" corresp="#smg_44"><p corresp="#smg_44.01">What is called the epitome is like that. Seek the essence of the truth, without being turned into untruth! What is your analogy? Like the fibres of the palm rib broom. Their number being great, they are held together (?, <foreign>kasigənan</foreign>) by the single tie. All the teachings are like that.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_44.02">The Holy Supreme, He creates what serves as the essence with respect to the direct perception (<foreign>pratyaksa</foreign>)*. It is true that the Witness knows about the demonic substance, which serves as the sin of the posture (<foreign>luṅguh</foreign>). It is true that the Witness will know about the one who has attachment which serves as its sin. The one without attachment serves as the supreme power in the penance (<foreign>tapa</foreign>). It is true that the Witness will know the unconsciousness which serves as its sin. The consciousness serves as its supreme power with regard to the esoteric <supplied reason="subaudible">teaching</supplied> (<foreign>sandi</foreign>). Do not let the Witness join them, insofar that such <supplied reason="subaudible">involvement</supplied> is sinful. Those should be considered cautiously by the servant of the <foreign>dharma</foreign>, according to the great scholar.</p>
2110<p corresp="#smg_44.03">The following is called the beginning of writing. What is pointed out by the scholar about the beginning of writing, absolutely without any doubt whatsoever? What serves as the essence of it? As follows: the muscle of the right and left hands, the writing on the palms of the hands. Those are called the hands. There is nothing lacking in them, there is nothing that is slipping away from the moving hands.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_44.04">The following is the second <supplied reason="subaudible">part</supplied> of writing. Its form is as follows: the manifestation is the riddle words. It serves as the challenge of the scholar. What does it refer to? As follows: both pupils. The meaning is: the conduct of life is the conduct of speech; the meaning is: the conduct of intellect is the conduct of knowledge, the conduct of esoteric <supplied reason="subaudible">knowledge</supplied> is the conduct of mind. Likewise, the individualized divine emanation and the supreme are united with the secret, their nature is to disappear simultaneously all together. There is not <supplied reason="subaudible">even</supplied> the knowledge that they have already been released. They are the content of the second part of writing, according to the foremost master, which is paid full attention by the servant of dharma.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_44.05">The following is the third part of writing, the beginning of the master discussing the secret, that is the origin of the self divine emanation. If one realizes its own self, that is the Supreme Dharma. It releases from the world, it departs from the body. The breath, the speech, and the mind are not embodied. Moreover, <supplied reason="subaudible">they are</supplied> the ultimate void and emptiness, free from disturbance, pure, unobstructed. That is the perpetual dharma that exists in the body.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_44.06">It continuously flames and shines, not being extinguished by day and night, also in the manifest and unmanifest <supplied reason="subaudible">worlds</supplied>. It has been shown based on the true nature (vastu) by the master. You should not have any doubt! They are the content of the third part of writing, which is paid full attention by the servant of dharma, it is the word of the lord of yogins.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_44.07">The following is called the fixed number of four. The meaning is: life, death, sleep, and unconsciousness. Those serve as the place of the Witness in material and immaterial reality. They are shown by the scholar to the servant of the dharma.</p>
2115<p corresp="#smg_44.08">The gross body is death. You see the body, small and little. It is seen for an instant only. As for the subtle body, that is regarded as sleep, it serves as your body while dreaming. As for the pure body, that is called the unconsciousness which is void, absence, and the ultimate reality. These are called the fixed number of four. The Witness, the life and the Soul does not manifest: clear, silent, unhindered; perpetual, steadfast, independent. All beings are like that. Those <supplied reason="subaudible">i.e. kalakar pat</supplied> are called the king of sins. The King Witness does not manifest in material and immaterial world, meaning that it serves as the essence of the fixed number of four. It should be thought carefully by my child, the servant of the dharma, according to the lord of yogins.</p> </div> <!-- mari saṁsaya ta kita denya, mari meliḥ na<space type="binding-hole"/> ta kita, saṁ hya pramana, manilvalita saṁ hya visesa, ka, tan· na svaga, tar nahala, tar na hayu, tar na su<lb n="35v4" break="no"/>ka, tar na duka, Iya ta rasaniṁ pati ṅaranya, katəmvan ikaṁ manivan·, ri sala niskala, Apa ta maryikən·n ika hala, hala hayu, suka duka, ṅəkeri bvana sarira, ṅaniveḥ Ikaṁ sarvvajan·ma kabeḥ <!-\-SSMG_L621_36r.JPG-\->
.<pb n="36r"/>
.<lb n="36r1"/>Ana saṁ hyaṁ pramana, juga tan· hana vaneḥ nihan· sinaṁguḥ rahasye pandi ṅaranya, -->
.<div n="45" corresp="#smg_45"><p corresp="#smg_45.01">The following is called the secret of the scholar. What is the detailed explanation of it? As follows, there is your analogy: like the Witness, after the individualized divine emanation is blissful (<foreign>hayu</foreign>), when it is released from the world, freed from the body, <supplied reason="subaudible">it</supplied> being only the everlasting consciousness and the deepest point of esoteric knowledge. What is the everlasting consciousness and the deepest point of esoteric knowledge?</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_45.02">Their meanings are as follows: “As the fire <supplied reason="subaudible">which is</supplied> in every piece of wood is not perceived because of <supplied reason="subaudible">its</supplied> subtlety.” The meaning is: it is not found. You have ceased to be doubtful about it, you, the individualized divine emanation, have ceased to be hesitant, the holy supreme has ceased to be tremulous.</p>
2120<p corresp="#smg_45.03">The meaning is: it is not heaven, nor the bad, nor the goodness, nor the joy, nor the sorrow. That is called the essence of death. The experience of The Witness in the material and immaterial <supplied reason="subaudible">worlds</supplied>. What causes one to give up the bad and the good, the joy and the sorrow, here in the world and the body, and in all beings? It is only the individualized divine emanation, nothing else. Those are called the secrets of the scholar; they should be clearly understood by the servant of the dharma, according to the noble scholar, 4.</p></div>
.<div n="46" corresp="#smg_46"><p corresp="#smg_46.01">As follows are the instruction words, the climax of the scholar who ceases to teach the servant of the dharma, the climax of the teacher who ceases to teach the pupil, the climax of the pupil who ceases to ask the teacher.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_46.02">How is it so? As follows: like the jewel with the crystal, likewise are the scholar and the servant of the dharma. If they have understood about all holy dharmas, each of them, the servant of the dharma and the teacher are one, the one who teaches and the one who asks are united. The scholar has ceased to teach the servant of the dharma, the lord of yogin has ceased to ask.</p>
.<p corresp="#smg_46.03">The meaning is: if all of them already know, also, their individualized divine emanations are equally priceless, meaning that they equally return to their original nature. That is called the instruction words. It should be paid attention to by the servant of the dharma, according to the noble great scholar.</p></div>
.<div n="47" corresp="#smg_47"><p corresp="#smg_47.01">This is what should be paid attention to, the holy book called Sasana Mahaguru. It has been completely written in the fourth month. Accomplishing the writing at the region Mahapavitra on Mount Jedang. The product of an ugly side job. The one who writes is an amateur boy who weighs the gold. Apologize for the ugly writing like the trace of a crab in the sand. If something is missing, please add it, if it is too much, please reduce it, because it is the work of a stupid one.</p> </div> </div>
2125 <div type="commentary"><p/></div>
. <div type="bibliography">
. <p/>
. <listBibl>
. <bibl/>

.
. </div>
. </body>
. </text>

A gap due to loss intervenes in B.ṅaranna A
...]ṅa Bya ta sinaṅguh tri-kaya mandala parisuda ṅaranya, liṅ saṅ pandita A
Both manuscripts share this passage. However, B has an extention: hana ta ya saṁ hyiṁ tri-kaya mandala [...] cai pari ṅaran:iṁ bvana, suda ṅaran:iṁ pvaE, Ugas bvana lambha, mətu bvana paR̥k· tri ṅaran:iṅ hulu, kaya ṅaran:iṁ tri-kaya mandala parisuda, ṅa, byitanyi, kayatnak:ən· na saṁ sevaka darma. Probably B represents an original text, but I cannot reconstruct the passage since the manuscript is too damage.silokanya A
